    39. 39
      Li, B.; Gu, M.; Nie, Z.; Shao, Y.; Luo, Q.; Wei, X.; Li, X.; Xiao, J.; Wang, C.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. Bismuth Nanoparticle Decorating Graphite Felt as a High-Performance Electrode for an All-Vanadium Redox Flow Battery Nano Lett. 2013, 13 (3) 1330– 1335 DOI: 10.1021/nl400223v
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      39
      Bismuth nanoparticle decorating graphite felt as a high-performance electrode for an all-vanadium redox flow battery
      Li, Bin; Gu, Meng; Nie, Zimin; Shao, Yuyan; Luo, Qingtao; Wei, Xiaoliang; Li, Xiaolin; Xiao, Jie; Wang, Chongmin; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
      Nano Letters (2013), 13 (3), 1330-1335CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
      Employing electrolytes contg. Bi3+, bismuth nanoparticles are synchronously electrodeposited onto the surface of a graphite felt electrode during operation of an all-vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB). The influence of the Bi nanoparticles on the electrochem. performance of the VRFB is thoroughly investigated. It is confirmed that Bi is only present at the neg. electrode and facilitates the redox reaction between V(II) and V(III). However, the Bi nanoparticles significantly improve the electrochem. performance of VRFB cells by enhancing the kinetics of the sluggish V(II)/V(III) redox reaction, esp. under high power operation. The energy efficiency is increased by 11% at high c.d. (150 mA·cm-2) owing to faster charge transfer as compared with one without Bi. The results suggest that using Bi nanoparticles in place of noble metals offers great promise as high-performance electrodes for VRFB application.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXitlCitb0%253D&md5=02ccbc1ae4f768b6868d9aff119946e8

      Zeng, Y.; Zhao, T.; An, L.; Zhou, X.; Wei, L. A comparative study of all-vanadium and iron-chromium redox flow batteries for large-scale energy storage J. Power Sources 2015, 300, 438– 443 DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.09.100
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      40
      A comparative study of all-vanadium and iron-chromium redox flow batteries for large-scale energy storage
      Zeng, Y. K.; Zhao, T. S.; An, L.; Zhou, X. L.; Wei, L.
      Journal of Power Sources (2015), 300 (), 438-443CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The promise of redox flow batteries (RFBs) utilizing sol. redox couples, such as all vanadium ions as well as iron and chromium ions, is becoming increasingly recognized for large-scale energy storage of renewables such as wind and solar, owing to their unique advantages including scaling ability, intrinsic safety, and long cycle life. An ongoing question assocd. with these two RFBs is detg. whether the vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB) or iron-chromium redox flow battery (ICRFB) is more suitable and competitive for large-scale energy storage. To address this concern, a comparative study has been conducted for the two types of battery based on their charge-discharge performance, cycle performance, and capital cost. It is found that: (i) the two batteries have similar energy efficiencies at high current densities; (ii) the ICRFB exhibits a higher capacity decay rate than does the VRFB; and (iii) the ICRFB is much less expensive in capital costs when operated at high power densities or at large capacities.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhs1WjsbbJ&md5=7109be4a44d17d0863f2ae6e3c0e631d

      Li, B.; Liu, J.; Nie, Z.; Wang, W.; Reed, D.; Liu, J.; McGrail, P.; Sprenkle, V. Metal Organic Frameworks as Highly Active Electrocatalysts for High-Energy Density, Aqueous Zinc-Polyiodide Redox Flow Batteries Nano Lett. 2016, 16 (7) 4335– 4340 DOI: 10.1021/acs.nanolett.6b01426
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      43
      Metal-Organic Frameworks as Highly Active Electrocatalysts for High-Energy Density, Aqueous Zinc-Polyiodide Redox Flow Batteries
      Li, Bin; Liu, Jian; Nie, Zimin; Wang, Wei; Reed, David; Liu, Jun; McGrail, Pete; Sprenkle, Vincent
      Nano Letters (2016), 16 (7), 4335-4340CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
      The new aq. zinc-polyiodide redox flow battery (RFB) system with highly sol. active materials as well as ambipolar and bifunctional designs demonstrated significantly enhanced energy d., which shows great potential to reduce RFB cost. However, the poor kinetic reversibility and electrochem. activity of the redox reaction of I3-/I- couples on graphite felts (GFs) electrode can result in low energy efficiency. Two nanoporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), MIL-125-NH2 and UiO-66-CH3, that have high surface areas when introduced to GF surfaces accelerated the I3-/I- redox reaction. The flow cell with MOF-modified GFs serving as a pos. electrode showed higher energy efficiency than the pristine GFs; increases of ∼ 6.4 and 2.7% occurred at the c.d. of 30 mA/cm2 for MIL-125-NH2 and UiO-66-CH3, resp. Moreover, UiO-66-CH3 is more promising due to its excellent chem. stability in the weakly acidic electrolyte. This letter highlights a way for MOFs to be used in the field of RFBs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XpsFGqtrc%253D&md5=fe8e931daa0a0898208d7d6b8398e47e

      Lin, G.; Chong, P. Y.; Yarlagadda, V.; Nguyen, T. V.; Wycisk, R. J.; Pintauro, P. N.; Bates, M.; Mukerjee, S.; Tucker, M. C.; Weber, A. Z. Advanced Hydrogen-Bromine Flow Batteries with Improved Efficiency, Durability and Cost J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (1) A5049– A5056 DOI: 10.1149/2.0071601jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      45
      Advanced Hydrogen-Bromine Flow Batteries with Improved Efficiency, Durability and Cost
      Lin, G.; Chong, P. Y.; Yarlagadda, V.; Nguyen, T. V.; Wycisk, R. J.; Pintauro, P. N.; Bates, M.; Mukerjee, S.; Tucker, M. C.; Weber, A. Z.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5049-A5056CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      The hydrogen/bromine flow battery is a promising candidate for large-scale energy storage due to fast kinetics, highly reversible reactions and low chem. costs. However, today's conventional hydrogen/bromine flow batteries use membrane materials (such as Nafion), platinum catalysts, and carbon-paper electrode materials that are expensive. In addn., platinum catalysts can be poisoned and corroded when exposed to HBr and Br2, compromising system lifetime. To reduce the cost and increase the durability of H2/Br2 flow batteries, new materials are developed. The new Nafion/ polyvinylidene fluoride electrospun composite membranes have high perm-selectivity at a fraction of the cost of Nafion membranes; the new nitrogen-functionalized platinum-iridium catalyst possesses excellent activity and durability in HBr/Br2 environment; and the new carbon-nanotube-based Br2 electrodes can achieve equal or better performance with less materials when compared to baseline electrode materials. Preliminary cost anal. shows that the new materials reduce H2/Br2 flow-battery energy-storage system stack and system costs significantly. The resulting advanced H2/Br2 flow batteries offer high power, high efficiency, substantially increased durability, and expected reduced cost.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr7K&md5=944e0640a17aabc9c68e39f6524d3da9

      Zhao, Y.; Byon, H. High-Performance Lithium-Iodine Flow Battery Adv. Energy Mater. 2013, 3 (12) 1630– 1635 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201300627
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46
      High-Performance Lithium-Iodine Flow Battery
      Zhao, Yu; Byon, Hye Ryung
      Advanced Energy Materials (2013), 3 (12), 1630-1635CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A cathode-flow lithium-iodine (Li-I) battery is proposed operating by the triiodide/iodide (I3-/I-) redox couple in aq. soln. The aq. Li-I battery has noticeably high energy d. (≈0.28 kWh kg-1cell) because of the considerable soly. of LiI in aq. soln. (≈8.2 m) and reasonably high power d. (≈130 mW cm-2 at a current rate of 60 mA cm-2, 328 K). In the operation of cathode-flow mode, the Li-I battery attains high storage capacity (≈90% of the theor. capacity), Coulombic efficiency (100% ± 1% in 2-20 cycles) and cyclic performance (>99% capacity retention for 20 cycles) up to total capacity of 100 mAh.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      48
      Semi-solid lithium rechargeable flow battery
      Duduta, Mihai; Ho, Bryan; Wood, Vanessa C.; Limthongkul, Pimpa; Brunini, Victor E.; Carter, W. Craig; Chiang, Yet-Ming
      Advanced Energy Materials (2011), 1 (4), 511-516CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      This study propose and demonstrate a new storage concept, the semi-solid flow cell (SSFC) which combines the high energy d. of rechargeable batteries with the flexible and scalable architecture of fuel cells and flow batteries. In contrast to previous flow batteries, energy is stored in suspensions of solid storage compds. to and from which charge transfer is accomplished via dil. yet percolating networks of nanoscale conductors. These novel electrochem. composites constitute flowable semi-solid fuels that are here charged and discharged in prototype flow cells. Potential advantages of the SSFC approach include projected system-level energy densities that are more than ten times those of aq. flow batteries , and the simplified low-cost manufg. of large-scale storage systems compared to conventional lithium-ion batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXpsF2rsbw%253D&md5=c5204faf69475791b7207a156d2d65ae

      Hu, B.; DeBruler, C.; Rhodes, Z.; Liu, T. L. Long-Cycling Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Battery (AORFB) toward Sustainable and Safe Energy Storage J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139 (3) 1207– 1214 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b10984
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      49
      Long-Cycling Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Battery (AORFB) toward Sustainable and Safe Energy Storage
      Hu, Bo; DeBruler, Camden; Rhodes, Zayn; Liu, T. Leo
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (3), 1207-1214CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are a viable technol. to store renewable energy in the form of electricity that can be supplied to electricity grids. However, wide-spread implementation of traditional RFBs, such as Vanadium and Zn-Br2 RFBs is limited due to a no. of challenges related to materials, including low abundance and high costs of redox active metals, expensive separators, active material crossover, and corrosive and hazardous electrolytes. To address these challenges, a neutral aq. org. redox flow battery (AORFB) technol. is demonstrated utilizing a newly designed cathode electrolyte contg. a highly water-sol. ferrocene mol. Specifically, water sol. (ferrocenylmethyl)trimethylammonium chloride (FcNCl, 4.0 M in H2O, 107.2 Ah/L, and 3.0 M in 2.0 NaCl, 80.4 Ah/L) and N1-ferrocenylmethyl-N1,N1,N2,N2,N2-pentamethylpropane-1,2-diaminium dibromide, (FcN2Br2, 3.1 M in H2O, 83.1 Ah/L, and 2.0 M in 2.0 M NaCl, 53.5 Ah/L) were synthesized through structural decoration of hydrophobic ferrocene with synergetic hydrophilic functionalities including an ammonium cation group and a halide anion. When paired with Me viologen (MV) as an anolyte, resulting FcNCl/MV and FcN2Br2/MV AORFBs were operated in noncorrosive neutral NaCl supporting electrolytes using a low cost anion exchange membrane. These ferrocene/MV AORFBs are characterized as having high theor. energy d. (45.5 Wh/L), and excellent cycling performance from 40-100 mA/cm2. Notably, the FcNCl/MV AORFBs (demonstrated at 7.0 and 9.9 Wh/L) exhibited unprecedented long cycling performance, 700 cycles at 60 mA/cm2 with 99.99% capacity retention per cycle, and delivered power d. up to 125 mW/cm2. These AORFBs are built from earth abundant elements and environmentally benign, thus represent a promising choice for sustainable and safe energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitV2nurfK&md5=0de6d3576463a0604d10018443fb3cea

      51
      A metal-free organic-inorganic aqueous flow battery
      Huskinson, Brian; Marshak, Michael P.; Suh, Changwon; Er, Sueleyman; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Galvin, Cooper J.; Chen, Xudong; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2014), 505 (7482), 195-198CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A class of energy storage materials that exploits the favorable chem. and electrochem. properties of a family of mols. known as quinones is described. The metal-free flow battery based on the redox chem. of 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) is demonstrated. AQDS undergoes extremely rapid and reversible 2-electron 2-proton redn. on a glassy C electrode in H2SO4. An aq. flow battery with inexpensive C electrodes, combining the quinone/hydroquinone couple with the Br2/Br- redox couple, yields a peak galvanic power d. exceeding 0.6 W cm-2 at 1.3 A cm-2. Cycling of this quinone-bromide flow battery showed >99% storage capacity retention per cycle. The org. anthraquinone species can be synthesized from inexpensive commodity chems. This org. approach permits tuning of important properties such as the redn. potential and soly. by adding functional groups: for example, the addn. of 2 hydroxy groups to AQDS increases the open circuit potential of the cell by 11% and a pathway for further increases in cell voltage is described. The use of π-arom. redox-active org. mols. instead of redox-active metals represents a new and promising direction for realizing massive elec. energy storage at greatly reduced cost.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Shin, S.; Yun, S.; Moon, S. A review of current developments in non-aqueous redox flow batteries: characterization of their membranes for design perspective RSC Adv. 2013, 3 (24) 9095– 9116 DOI: 10.1039/c3ra00115f
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      53
      A review of current developments in non-aqueous redox flow batteries: characterization of their membranes for design perspective
      Shin, Sung-Hee; Yun, Sung-Hyun; Moon, Seung-Hyeon
      RSC Advances (2013), 3 (24), 9095-9116CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. The non-aq. redox flow battery (RFB) is one of the emerging large-scale energy storage systems that may overcome the low energy d. limited by breakdown of water at a high voltage in aq. RFBs. Yet development of the non-aq. RFB is at an early stage, so its components are not thoroughly understood. As a key component of non-aq. RFBs, the role of the membrane is to suppress cross-contamination between the anolyte and catholyte confined in two sep. compartments, and to transport the charge carrier ions selectively for the completion of the circuit during cell operation. In this review, recent studies on non-aq. redox flow systems are summarized including redox couples, electrolytes, and systems including membranes. A focus is placed on comparison of battery performance in terms of the current and power d. through membranes. In addn., we introduce syntheses and characterization of membranes used for non-aq. RFBs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Zhao, Y.; Ding, Y.; Li, Y.; Peng, L.; Byon, H.; Goodenough, J. B.; Yu, G. A chemistry and material perspective on lithium redox flow batteries towards high-density electrical energy storage Chem. Soc. Rev. 2015, 44 (22) 7968– 7996 DOI: 10.1039/C5CS00289C
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      55
      A chemistry and material perspective on lithium redox flow batteries towards high-density electrical energy storage
      Zhao, Yu; Ding, Yu; Li, Yutao; Peng, Lele; Byon, Hye Ryung; Goodenough, John B.; Yu, Guihua
      Chemical Society Reviews (2015), 44 (22), 7968-7996CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Elec. energy storage system such as secondary batteries is the principle power source for portable electronics, elec. vehicles and stationary energy storage. As an emerging battery technol., Li-redox flow batteries inherit the advantageous features of modular design of conventional redox flow batteries and high voltage and energy efficiency of Li-ion batteries, showing great promise as efficient elec. energy storage system in transportation, com., and residential applications. The chem. of lithium redox flow batteries with aq. or non-aq. electrolyte enables widened electrochem. potential window thus may provide much greater energy d. and efficiency than conventional redox flow batteries based on proton chem. This Review summarizes the design rationale, fundamentals and characterization of Li-redox flow batteries from a chem. and material perspective, with particular emphasis on the new chemistries and materials. The latest advances and assocd. challenges/opportunities are comprehensively discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtlejsr7K&md5=3e22599013c4b807647e463678e26b64

      Fan, F. Y.; Woodford, W. H.; Li, Z.; Baram, N.; Smith, K. C.; Helal, A.; McKinley, G. H.; Carter, W. C.; Chiang, Y. M. Polysulfide Flow Batteries Enabled by Percolating Nanoscale Conductor Networks Nano Lett. 2014, 14 (4) 2210– 2218 DOI: 10.1021/nl500740t
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      56
      Polysulfide Flow Batteries Enabled by Percolating Nanoscale Conductor Networks
      Fan, Frank Y.; Woodford, William H.; Li, Zheng; Baram, Nir; Smith, Kyle C.; Helal, Ahmed; McKinley, Gareth H.; Carter, W. Craig; Chiang, Yet-Ming
      Nano Letters (2014), 14 (4), 2210-2218CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
      A new approach to flow battery design is demonstrated wherein diffusion-limited aggregation of nanoscale conductor particles at ∼1 vol.% concn. is used to impart mixed electronic-ionic cond. to redox solns., forming flow electrodes with embedded current collector networks that self-heal after shear. Lithium polysulfide flow cathodes of this architecture exhibit electrochem. activity that is distributed throughout the vol. of flow electrodes rather than being confined to surfaces of stationary current collectors. The nanoscale network architecture enables cycling of polysulfide solns. deep into pptn. regimes that historically have shown poor capacity utilization and reversibility and may thereby enable new flow battery designs of higher energy d. and lower system cost. Lithium polysulfide half-flow cells operating in both continuous and intermittent flow mode are demonstrated for the first time.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXjsFOmurw%253D&md5=f9206be48184f74b7c55a4c0d963eeea
    57. 57
      Lu, Y.; Goodenough, J. B. Rechargeable alkali-ion cathode-flow battery J. Mater. Chem. 2011, 21 (27) 10113– 10117 DOI: 10.1039/c0jm04222f
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      57
      Rechargeable alkali-ion cathode-flow battery
      Lu, Yuhao; Goodenough, John B.
      Journal of Materials Chemistry (2011), 21 (27), 10113-10117CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The authors provide proof of the concept of a lithium battery configuration contg. an aq. cathode in a flow-through mode. A room-temp., rechargeable alkali-ion battery with a com. available Li+-ion solid-electrolyte sepg. a Li0 anode and an org. liq.-carbonate electrolyte on one side and, on the other, an aq. cathode contg. 0.1 M K3Fe(CN)6 has been demonstrated to give high efficiency elec. energy storage at 3.40 V; it is capable of matching the capacity of the Li0 anode if operated with the aq. cathode in a flow-through mode. The resistance of the solid electrolyte rather than the flow rate of the cathode detd. the power d. of the test cell. The concept can be used with a more-abundant Na0 anode and a Na+-ion solid electrolyte. The results call for the development of an alkali-ion solid-electrolyte separator with a smaller resistance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXotFSnurk%253D&md5=ab9c31faf5584188e49a6c1302353da4

      [Crossref], Google Scholar

    59. 59
      Yang, Y.; Zheng, G.; Cui, Y. A membrane-free lithium/polysulfide semi-liquid battery for large-scale energy storage Energy Environ. Sci. 2013, 6 (5) 1552– 1558 DOI: 10.1039/c3ee00072a
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      59
      A membrane-free lithium/polysulfide semi-liquid battery for large-scale energy storage
      Yang, Yuan; Zheng, Guangyuan; Cui, Yi
      Energy & Environmental Science (2013), 6 (5), 1552-1558CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Large-scale energy storage represents a key challenge for renewable energy and new systems with low cost, high energy d. and long cycle life are desired. In this article, we develop a new lithium/polysulfide (Li/PS) semi-liq. battery for large-scale energy storage, with lithium polysulfide (Li2S8) in ether solvent as a catholyte and metallic lithium as an anode. Unlike previous work on Li/S batteries with discharge products such as solid state Li2S2 and Li2S, the catholyte is designed to cycle only in the range between sulfur and Li2S4. Consequently all detrimental effects due to the formation and vol. expansion of solid Li2S2/Li2S are avoided. This novel strategy results in excellent cycle life and compatibility with flow battery design. The proof-of-concept Li/PS battery could reach a high energy d. of 170 W h kg-1 and 190 W h L-1 for large scale storage at the soly. limit, while keeping the advantages of hybrid flow batteries. We demonstrated that, with a 5 M Li2S8 catholyte, energy densities of 97 W h kg-1 and 108 W h L-1 can be achieved. As the lithium surface is well passivated by LiNO3 additive in ether solvent, internal shuttle effect is largely eliminated and thus excellent performance over 2000 cycles is achieved with a const. capacity of 200 mA h g-1. This new system can operate without the expensive ion-selective membrane, and it is attractive for large-scale energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmvVens7g%253D&md5=15c202ffdf79855ef9e438a7635b118a

      Pan, H.; Wei, X.; Henderson, W. A.; Shao, Y.; Chen, J.; Bhattacharya, P.; Xiao, J.; Liu, J. On the Way Toward Understanding Solution Chemistry of Lithium Polysulfides for High Energy Li-S Redox Flow Batteries Adv. Energy Mater. 2015, 5 (16) 1500113 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201500113
      [Crossref], Google Scholar

    61. 61
      Wei, X.; Cosimbescu, L.; Xu, W.; Hu, J.; Vijayakumar, M.; Feng, J.; Hu, M. Y.; Deng, X.; Xiao, J.; Liu, J.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. Towards High-Performance Nonaqueous Redox Flow Electrolyte Via Ionic Modification of Active Species Adv. Energy Mater. 2015, 5 (1) 1400678 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201400678
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      61
      Towards High-Performance Nonaqueous Redox Flow Electrolyte Via Ionic Modification of Active Species
      Wei, Xiaoliang; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Xu, Wu; Hu, Jian Zhi; Vijayakumar, M.; Feng, Ju; Hu, Mary Y.; Deng, Xuchu; Xiao, Jie; Liu, Jun; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
      Advanced Energy Materials (2015), 5 (1), 1400678/1-1400678/7CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      Nonaq. redox flow batteries are emerging flow-based energy storage technologies that have the potential for higher energy densities than their aq. counterparts because of their wider voltage windows. However, their performance has lagged far behind their inherent capability due to one major limitation of low soly. of the redox species. Here, a mol. structure engineering strategy towards high performance nonaq. electrolyte is reported with significantly increased soly. Its performance outweighs that of the state-of-the-art nonaq. redox flow batteries. In particular, an ionic-derivatized ferrocene compd. is designed and synthesized that has more than 20 times increased soly. in the supporting electrolyte. The solvation chem. of the modified ferrocene compd. Electrochem. cycling testing in a hybrid lithium-org. redox flow battery using the as-synthesized ionic-derivatized ferrocene as the catholyte active material demonstrates that the incorporation of the ionic-charged pendant significantly improves the system energy d. When coupled with a lithium-graphite hybrid anode, the hybrid flow battery exhibits a cell voltage of 3.49 V, energy d. about 50 Wh L-1, and energy efficiency over 75%. These results reveal a generic design route towards high performance nonaq. electrolyte by rational functionalization of the org. redox species with selective ligand.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXis1yqtA%253D%253D&md5=10f108fb4f5c8314e90e45b5d003185d
    62. 62
      Zhao, Y.; Ding, Y.; Song, J.; Li, G.; Dong, G.; Goodenough, J. B.; Yu, G. Sustainable Electrical Energy Storage through the Ferrocene/Ferrocenium Redox Reaction in Aprotic Electrolyte Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2014, 53 (41) 11036– 11040 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201406135
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      62
      Sustainable Electrical Energy Storage through the Ferrocene/Ferrocenium Redox Reaction in Aprotic Electrolyte
      Zhao, Yu; Ding, Yu; Song, Jie; Li, Gang; Dong, Guangbin; Goodenough, John B.; Yu, Guihua
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2014), 53 (41), 11036-11040CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The large-scale, cost-effective storage of elec. energy obtained from the growing deployment of wind and solar power is critically needed for the integration into the grid of these renewable energy sources. Rechargeable batteries having a redox-flow cathode represent a viable soln. for either a Li-ion or a Na-ion battery provided a suitable low-cost redox mol. sol. in an aprotic electrolyte can be identified that is stable for repeated cycling and does not cross the separator membrane to the anode. Here the authors demonstrate an environmentally friendly, low-cost ferrocene/ferrocenium mol. redox couple that shows ∼95% energy efficiency and ∼90% capacity retention after 250 full charge/discharge cycles.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVWqtbzJ&md5=b4df875f1bcd965c782233b347c42503

      Liu, Q.; Sleightholme, A. E. S.; Shinkle, A. A.; Li, Y.; Thompson, L. T. Non-aqueous vanadium acetylacetonate electrolyte for redox flow batteries Electrochem. Commun. 2009, 11 (12) 2312– 2315 DOI: 10.1016/j.elecom.2009.10.006
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      63
      Non-aqueous vanadium acetylacetonate electrolyte for redox flow batteries
      Liu, Qinghua; Sleightholme, Alice E. S.; Shinkle, Aaron A.; Li, Yongdan; Thompson, Levi T.
      Electrochemistry Communications (2009), 11 (12), 2312-2315CODEN: ECCMF9; ISSN:1388-2481. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The electrochem. of a single-component redox flow battery employing vanadium(III) acetylacetonate in acetonitrile and tetraethylammonium tetrafluoroborate was investigated. The electrode kinetics of the anodic and cathodic reactions were studied using cyclic voltammetry. The V(II)/V(III) and V(III)/V(IV) couples were quasi-reversible and together yielded a cell potential of 2.2 V. The diffusion coeff. for vanadium acetylacetonate was estd. to be in the range of 1.8-2.9 × 10-6 cm2 s-1 at room temp. The charge-discharge characteristics of this system were evaluated in an H-type glass cell, and coulombic efficiencies near 50% were achieved.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVGls7%252FJ&md5=90c53da1a7d7478d84e87d483a4101d9

      Pratt, H. D.; Hudak, N. S.; Fang, X.; Anderson, T. M. A polyoxometalate flow battery J. Power Sources 2013, 236, 259– 264 DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2013.02.056
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      64
      A polyoxometalate flow battery
      Pratt, Harry D., III; Hudak, Nicholas S.; Fang, Xikui; Anderson, Travis M.
      Journal of Power Sources (2013), 236 (), 259-264CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A redox flow battery utilizing two, three-electron polyoxometalate redox couples (SiVV3WVI9O407-/SiVIV3WVI9O4010- and SiVIV3WVI9O4010-/SiVIV3WV3WVI6O4013-) was investigated for use in stationary storage in either aq. or non-aq. conditions. The aq. battery had coulombic efficiencies greater than 95% with relatively low capacity fading over 100 cycles. IR studies showed there was no decompn. of the compd. under these conditions. The non-aq. analog had a higher operating voltage but at the expense of coulombic efficiency. The spontaneous formation of these clusters by self-assembly facilitates recovery of the battery after being subjected to reversed polarity. Polyoxometalates offer a new approach to stationary storage materials because they are capable of undergoing multi-electron reactions and are stable over a wide range of pH values and temps.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmsFahsLo%253D&md5=5cc0ba6e957fc4f9f27ece2d1bebb286

      Application of Redox Non-Innocent Ligands to Non-Aqueous Flow Battery Electrolytes
      Cappillino, Patrick J.; Pratt, Harry D., III; Hudak, Nicholas S.; Tomson, Neil C.; Anderson, Travis M.; Anstey, Mitchell R.
      Advanced Energy Materials (2014), 4 (1), 1300566/1-1300566/4CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      In this paper, the author reports a new, non-aq. redox flow batteries (RFB) electrolyte based on tetramethyl- and tetraethylammonium salts of tris(mnt)vanadium(IV) ([V(mnt)3]2-; mnt = (NC)2C2S22-), 1a and 1b , resp., including their battery performance in a static (i.e., non-flowing) cell. The dithiolate moieties in this complex have been previously demonstrated to be redox non-innocent ligands (NIL), as they are known to participate in electrochem. events sep. from those o f the vanadium center to which they are bound.

      Sevov, C. S.; Fisher, S. L.; Thompson, L. T.; Sanford, M. S. Mechanism-Based Development of a Low-Potential, Soluble, and Cyclable Multielectron Anolyte for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138 (47) 15378– 15384 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b07638
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      67
      Mechanism-Based Development of a Low-Potential, Soluble, and Cyclable Multielectron Anolyte for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
      Sevov, Christo S.; Fisher, Sydney L.; Thompson, Levi T.; Sanford, Melanie S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (47), 15378-15384CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The development of nonaq. redox flow batteries (NRFBs) was impeded by a lack of electroactive compds. (anolytes and catholytes) with the necessary combination of (1) redox potentials that exceed the potential limits of water, (2) high soly. in nonaq. media, and (3) high stability toward electrochem. cycling. In addn., ideal materials would maintain all three of these properties over multiple electron transfer events, thereby providing a proportional increase in storage capacity. This paper describes the mechanism-based design of a new class of metal-coordination complexes (MCCs) as anolytes for NRFBs. The tridentate bipyridylimino isoindoline (BPI) ligands of these complexes were designed to enable multielectron redox events. These mols. were optimized using a combination of systematic variation of the BPI ligand and the metal center along with mechanistic investigations of the decompn. pathways that occur during electrochem. cycling. Ultimately, these studies led to the identification of nickel BPI complexes that could undergo stable charge-discharge cycling (<5% capacity loss over 200 cycles) as well as a deriv. that possesses the previously unprecedented combination of high soly. (>700 mM in CH3CN), multiple electron transfers at low redox potentials (-1.7 and -1.9 V vs. Ag/Ag+), and high stability in the charged state for days at high concn. Overall, the studies described herein have enabled the identification of a promising anolyte candidate for NRFBs and have also provided key insights into chem. design principles for future classes of MCC-based anolytes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVeltrbM&md5=75e147a17d9d4d823079ca928c81c9f0
    68. 68
      Liang, Y.; Tao, Z.; Chen, J. Organic Electrode Materials for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries Adv. Energy Mater. 2012, 2 (7) 742– 769 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201100795
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      68
      Organic electrode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries
      Liang, Yanliang; Tao, Zhanliang; Chen, Jun
      Advanced Energy Materials (2012), 2 (7), 742-769CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. Org. compds. offer new possibilities for high energy/power d., cost-effective, environmentally friendly, and functional rechargeable lithium batteries. For a long time, they have not constituted an important class of electrode materials, partly because of the large success and rapid development of inorg. intercalation compds. In recent years, however, exciting progress has been made, bringing org. electrodes to the attention of the energy storage community. Herein thirty years' research efforts in the field of org. compds. for rechargeable lithium batteries are summarized. The working principles, development history, and design strategies of these materials, including organosulfur compds., org. free radical compds., org. carbonyl compds., conducting polymers, non-conjugated redox polymers, and layered org. compds. are presented. The cell performances of these materials are compared, providing a comprehensive overview of the area, and straightforwardly revealing the advantages/disadvantages of each class of materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVOrtLnP&md5=1a37e1faec914ba6e286b1ea1b281a77

      Song, Z.; Zhou, H. Towards sustainable and versatile energy storage devices: an overview of organic electrode materials Energy Environ. Sci. 2013, 6 (8) 2280– 2301 DOI: 10.1039/c3ee40709h
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      69
      Towards sustainable and versatile energy storage devices: an overview of organic electrode materials
      Song, Zhiping; Zhou, Haoshen
      Energy & Environmental Science (2013), 6 (8), 2280-2301CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. As an alternative to conventional inorg. intercalation electrode materials, org. electrode materials are promising candidates for the next generation of sustainable and versatile energy storage devices. In this paper we provide an overview of org. electrode materials, including their fundamental knowledge, development history and perspective applications. Based on different orgs. including n-type, p-type and bipolar, we firstly analyzed their working principles, reaction mechanisms, electrochem. performances, advantages and challenges. To understand the development history and trends in org. electrode materials, we elaborate in detail various orgs. with different structures, including conducting polymers, organodisulfides, thioethers, nitroxyl radical polymers and conjugated carbonyl compds. The high electrochem. performance, in addn. with the unique features of orgs. such as flexibility, processability and structure diversity, provide them great perspective in various energy storage devices, including rechargeable Li/Na batteries, supercapacitors, thin film batteries, aq. rechargeable batteries, redox flow batteries and even all-org. batteries. It is expected that org. electrode materials will show their talents in the "post Li-ion battery" era, towards cheap, green, sustainable and versatile energy storage devices.

      The Chemistry of Redox-Flow Batteries
      Noack, Jens; Roznyatovskaya, Nataliya; Herr, Tatjana; Fischer, Peter
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (34), 9776-9809CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. The development of various redox-flow batteries for the storage of fluctuating renewable energy has intensified in recent years because of their peculiar ability to be scaled sep. in terms of energy and power, and therefore potentially to reduce the costs of energy storage. This has resulted in a considerable increase in the no. of publications on redox-flow batteries. This was a motivation to present a comprehensive and crit. overview of the features of this type of batteries, focusing mainly on the chem. of electrolytes and introducing a thorough systematic classification to reveal their potential for future development.

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      72
      Redox-Flow Batteries: From Metals to Organic Redox-Active Materials
      Winsberg, Jan; Hagemann, Tino; Janoschka, Tobias; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2017), 56 (3), 686-711CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Research on redox-flow batteries (RFBs) is currently experiencing a significant upturn, stimulated by the growing need to store increasing quantities of sustainably generated elec. energy. RFBs are promising candidates for the creation of smart grids, particularly when combined with photovoltaics and wind farms. To achieve the goal of "green", safe, and cost-efficient energy storage, research has shifted from metal-based materials to org. active materials in recent years. This Review presents an overview of various flow-battery systems. Relevant studies concerning their history are discussed as well as their development over the last few years from the classical inorg., to org./inorg., to RFBs with org. redox-active cathode and anode materials. Available technologies are analyzed in terms of their tech., economic, and environmental aspects; the advantages and limitations of these systems are also discussed. Further technol. challenges and prospective research possibilities are highlighted.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhsl2hsLrF&md5=ff596c450ef64fd500ffb2832d096756
    73. 73
      Leung, P.; Shah, A. A.; Sanz, L.; Flox, C.; Morante, J. R.; Xu, Q.; Mohamed, M. R.; Ponce de Leon, C.; Walsh, F. C. Recent developments in organic redox flow batteries: A Critical Review J. Power Sources 2017, 360, 243– 283 DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2017.05.057
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      73
      Recent developments in organic redox flow batteries: A critical review
      Leung, P.; Shah, A. A.; Sanz, L.; Flox, C.; Morante, J. R.; Xu, Q.; Mohamed, M. R.; Ponce de Leon, C.; Walsh, F. C.
      Journal of Power Sources (2017), 360 (), 243-283CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review is given. Redox flow batteries (RFBs) have emerged as prime candidates for energy storage on the medium and large scales, particularly at the grid scale. The demand for versatile energy storage continues to increase as more elec. energy is generated from intermittent renewable sources. A major barrier in the way of broad deployment and deep market penetration is the use of expensive metals as the active species in the electrolytes. The use of org. redox couples in aq. or non-aq. electrolytes is a promising approach to reducing the overall cost in long-term, since these materials can be low-cost and abundant. The performance of such redox couples can be tuned by modifying their chem. structure. In recent years, significant developments in org. redox flow batteries has taken place, with the introduction of new groups of highly sol. org. mols., capable of providing a cell voltage and charge capacity comparable to conventional metal-based systems. This paper summarizes the fundamental developments and characterization of org. redox flow batteries from both the chem. and materials perspectives. The latest advances, future challenges and opportunities for further development are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXpslWkurk%253D&md5=c6372d8657e4d3809a8c3f396fd6d415

      Ding, Y.; Zhao, Y.; Yu, G. A membrane-free ferrocene-based high-rate semiliquid battery Nano Lett. 2015, 15 (6) 4108– 4113 DOI: 10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b01224
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      75
      A Membrane-Free Ferrocene-Based High-Rate Semiliquid Battery
      Ding, Yu; Zhao, Yu; Yu, Guihua
      Nano Letters (2015), 15 (6), 4108-4113CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
      Here a ferrocene-based membrane-free, high-rate semiliquid battery is reported that takes advantage of a highly sol. ferrocene/ferrocenium redox couple in nonaq. phase. The designed battery exhibits stable capacity retention up to 94% of theor. capacity of ferrocene (145 mAh g-1) at a broad current rate up to 60 C owing to rapid mass transport in a liq. phase and fast redox kinetics. The diffusion coeff. and the std. reaction const. are detd. to be in the order of 10-6 cm2 s-1 and 10-1 cm s-1, resp., orders of magnitude greater than those in a solid-phase electrode and those in conventional redox flow batteries. Addnl., the battery demonstrates power d. and energy d. exceeding 1400 W L-1 and 40 Wh L-1, resp., and stable cyclability with capacity retention of ∼80% for 500 cycles. Compared with state-of-the-art energy storage technologies such as Li-ion batteries or conventional redox flow batteries, the proposed liq. battery shows the potential to be an efficient energy storage system with exceptionally high power and reasonable energy d.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXnslGjsLo%253D&md5=0e6085129eab72d2fb71427db814b440
    76. 76
      Cosimbescu, L.; Wei, X.; Vijayakumar, M.; Xu, W.; Helm, M. L.; Burton, S. D.; Sorensen, C. M.; Liu, J.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. Anion-Tunable Properties and Electrochemical Performance of Functionalized Ferrocene Compounds Sci. Rep. 2015, 14117 DOI: 10.1038/srep14117
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      76
      Anion-Tunable Properties and Electrochemical Performance of Functionalized Ferrocene Compounds
      Cosimbescu, Lelia; Wei, Xiaoliang; Vijayakumar, M.; Xu, Wu; Helm, Monte L.; Burton, Sarah D.; Sorensen, Christina M.; Liu, Jun; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
      Scientific Reports (2015), 5 (), 14117CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
      We report a series of ionically modified ferrocene compds. for hybrid lithium-org. non-aq. redox flow batteries, based on the ferrocene/ferrocenium redox couple as the active catholyte material. Tetraalkylammonium ionic moieties were incorporated into the ferrocene structure, in order to enhance the soly. of the otherwise relatively insol. ferrocene. The effect of various counter anions of the tetraalkylammonium ionized species appended to the ferrocene, such as bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide, hexafluorophosphate, perchlorate, tetrafluoroborate, and dicyanamide on the soly. of the ferrocene was investigated. The soln. chem. of the ferrocene species was studied, in order to understand the mechanism of soly. enhancement. Finally, the electrochem. performance of these ionized ferrocene species was evaluated and shown to have excellent cell efficiency and superior cycling stability.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFeis7nE&md5=4cc6fa05aa0f4dc0a6fd9d773b0973c6
    77. 77
      Hwang, B.; Park, M.; Kim, K. Ferrocene and Cobaltocene Derivatives for Non-Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries ChemSusChem 2015, 8 (2) 310– 314 DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201403021

    78. 78
      Cong, G.; Zhou, Y.; Li, Z.; Lu, Y. A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Enabled by a Low-Melting-Point Ferrocene Derivative ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (4) 869– 875 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b00115
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      78
      A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Enabled by a Low-Melting-Point Ferrocene Derivative
      Cong, Guangtao; Zhou, Yucun; Li, Zhejun; Lu, Yi-Chun
      ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (4), 869-875CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      Nonaq. redox flow batteries (NRFBs) exhibit a wide potential window (>3.0 V) but have been limited by the low soly. of the active materials. Here, the authors propose and demonstrate a high-energy-d. nonaq. redox flow battery based on a low-melting-point (37-40°) ferrocene deriv., 1,1'-dimethyl-ferrocene (DMFc), operated at its liq. state. The liq. redox-active DMFc not only contributes to high capacity but also acts as a solvating medium to the ion-conducting salts. Taking advantage of DMFc's high concn. (3 M), superior stability, and fast kinetics, the Li/DMFc battery achieves a high volumetric d. (∼68 A h L-1catholyte) with a high Coulombic efficiency (>95%) and high cycling stability. Exploiting a low-melting-point redox-active species at its melting state is a promising direction for developing high-energy-d. NRFBs for next-generation energy storage technologies.

      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXktlymsrs%253D&md5=9f245e5b91f28d45f901a08cab466650

      Beh, E. S.; De Porcellinis, D.; Gracia, R. L.; Xia, K.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. A Neutral pH Aqueous Organic-Organometallic Redox Flow Battery with Extremely High Capacity Retention ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (3) 639– 644 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b00019
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      79
      A Neutral pH Aqueous Organic-Organometallic Redox Flow Battery with Extremely High Capacity Retention
      Beh, Eugene S.; De Porcellinis, Diana; Gracia, Rebecca L.; Xia, Kay T.; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
      ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (3), 639-644CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      We demonstrate an aq. org. and organometallic redox flow battery utilizing reactants composed of only earth-abundant elements and operating at neutral pH. The pos. electrolyte contains bis((3-trimethylammonio)propyl)ferrocene dichloride, and the neg. electrolyte contains bis(3-trimethylammonio)propyl viologen tetrachloride; these are sepd. by an anion-conducting membrane passing chloride ions. Bis(trimethylammoniopropyl) functionalization leads to ∼2 M soly. for both reactants, suppresses higher-order chem. decompn. pathways, and reduces reactant crossover rates through the membrane. Unprecedented cycling stability was achieved with capacity retention of 99.9943%/cycle and 99.90%/day at a 1.3 M reactant concn., increasing to 99.9989%/cycle and 99.967%/day at 0.75-1.00 M; these represent the highest capacity retention rates reported to date vs. time and vs. cycle no. We discuss opportunities for future performance improvement, including chem. modification of a ferrocene center and reducing the membrane resistance without unacceptable increases in reactant crossover. This approach may provide the decadal lifetimes that enable org.-organometallic redox flow batteries to be cost-effective for grid-scale electricity storage, thereby enabling massive penetration of intermittent renewable electricity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXit12msrY%253D&md5=0b27106e1380cef821781323bd6cbeb7

      Deng, X.; Hu, M.; Wei, X.; Wang, W.; Mueller, K. T.; Chen, Z.; Hu, J. Nuclear magnetic resonance studies of the solvation structures of a high-performance nonaqueous redox flow electrolyte J. Power Sources 2016, 308, 172– 179 DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.12.005
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      81
      Nuclear magnetic resonance studies of the solvation structures of a high-performance nonaqueous redox flow electrolyte
      Deng, Xuchu; Hu, Mary; Wei, Xiaoliang; Wang, Wei; Mueller, Karl T.; Chen, Zhong; Hu, Jian Zhi
      Journal of Power Sources (2016), 308 (), 172-179CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Understanding the solvation structures of electrolytes is important for developing nonaq. redox flow batteries that hold considerable potential for future large scale energy storage systems. The utilization of an emerging ionic-derivatived ferrocene compd., ferrocenylmethyl di-Me Et ammonium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (Fc1N112-TFSI), has recently overcome the issue of soly. in the supporting electrolyte. In this work, 13C, 1H and 17O NMR investigations were carried out using electrolyte solns. consisting of Fc1N112-TFSI as the solute and the mixed alkyl carbonate as the solvent. It was obsd. that the spectra of 13C experience changes of chem. shifts while those of 17O undergo linewidth broadening, indicating interactions between solute and solvent mols. Quantum chem. calcns. of both mol. structures and chem. shifts (13C, 1H and 17O) are performed for interpreting exptl. results and for understanding the detailed solvation structures. The results indicate that Fc1N112-TFSI is dissocd. at varying degrees in mixed solvent depending on concns. At dil. solute concns., most Fc1N112+ and TFSI- are fully disassocd. with their own solvation shells formed by solvent mols. At satd. concn., Fc1N112+-TFSI- contact ion pairs are formed and the solvent mols. are preferentially interacting with the Fc rings rather than interacting with the ionic pendant arm of Fc1N112-TFSI.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitlSmtL8%253D&md5=128831497037e0deff8e49cee483a85c

      Han, K.; Rajput, N. N.; Wei, X.; Wang, W.; Hu, J.; Persson, K. A.; Mueller, K. T. Diffusional motion of redox centers in carbonate electrolytes J. Chem. Phys. 2014, 141 (10) 104509 DOI: 10.1063/1.4894481
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      82
      Diffusional motion of redox centers in carbonate electrolytes
      Han, Kee Sung; Rajput, Nav Nidhi; Wei, Xiaoliang; Wang, Wei; Hu, Jian Zhi; Persson, Kristin A.; Mueller, Karl T.
      Journal of Chemical Physics (2014), 141 (10), 104509/1-104509/8CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
      Ferrocene (Fc) and N-(ferrocenylmethyl)-N,N-dimethyl-N-ethylammonium bistrifluoromethyl-sulfonimide (Fc1N112-TFSI) were dissolved in carbonate solvents and self-diffusion coeffs. (D) of solutes and solvents were measured by 1H and 19F pulsed field gradient NMR (NMR) spectroscopy. The org. solvents were propylene carbonate (PC), Et Me carbonate (EMC), and a ternary mixt. that also includes ethylene carbonate (EC). Results from NMR studies over the temp. range of 0-50 °C and for various concns. (0.25-1.7 M) of Fc1N112-TFSI are compared to values of D simulated with classical mol. dynamics (MD). The measured self-diffusion coeffs. gradually decreased as the Fc1N112-TFSI concn. increased in all solvents. Since TFSI- has fluoromethyl groups (CF3), DTFSI could be measured sep. and the values found are larger than those for DFc1N112 in all samples measured. The EC, PC, and EMC have the same D in the neat solvent mixt. and when Fc is dissolved in EC/PC/EMC at a concn. of 0.2 M, probably due to the interactions between common carbonyl structures within EC, PC, and EMC. A difference in D (DPC < DEC < DEMC), and both a higher Ea for translational motion and higher effective viscosity for PC in the mixt. contg. Fc1N112-TFSI reflect the interaction between PC and Fc1N112+, which is a relatively stronger interaction than that between Fc1N112+ and other solvent species. In the EC/PC/EMC soln. that is satd. with Fc1N112-TFSI, we find that DPC = DEC = DEMC and Fc1N112+ and all components of the EC/PC/EMC soln. have the same Ea for translational motion, while the ratio DEC/PC/EMC/DFc1N112 is approx. 3. These results reflect the lack of available free vol. for independent diffusion in the satd. soln. The Fc1N112+ transference nos. lie around 0.4 and increase slightly as the temp. is increased in the PC and EMC solvents. The trends obsd. for D from simulations are in good agreement with exptl. results and provide mol. level understanding of the solvation structure of Fc1N112-TFSI dissolved in EC/PC/EMC. (c) 2014 American Institute of Physics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFeks7fJ&md5=0a06f83e145ef303570510d2595ba5b7

      Ding, Y.; Zhao, Y.; Li, Y.; Goodenough, J. B.; Yu, G. A high-performance all-metallocene-based, non-aqueous redox flow battery Energy Environ. Sci. 2017, 10, 491– 497 DOI: 10.1039/C6EE02057G
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      83
      A high-performance all-metallocene-based, non-aqueous redox flow battery
      Ding, Yu; Zhao, Yu; Li, Yutao; Goodenough, John B.; Yu, Guihua
      Energy & Environmental Science (2017), 10 (2), 491-497CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Here, a class of organometallic compds., metallocenes, are explored to serve as both catholyte and anolyte redox species for non-aq. lithium-based redox flow battery (Li-RFB) applications. The prototype of all-metallocene-based Li-RFB exploits ferrocene (FeCp2) and cobaltocene (CoCp2) as the redox-active cathode and anode, resp. The reaction rate consts. of metallocenes are detd. to be as high as 10-3 cm s-1, two orders greater than most redox-active materials applied in conventional redox flow batteries. This designed Li-RFB yields a working potential of 1.7 V, and by introduction of Me groups on the ligand rings of CoCp2, the working potential can be further increased to 2.1 V. The fabricated full cell shows capacity retention of over 99% per cycle with a coulombic efficiency (CE) of >95% and an energy efficiency of >85%. These results demonstrate a generic design route towards high performance non-aq. RFBs via rational screening and functionalization of metallocenes.

      Brushett, F. R.; Vaughey, J. T.; Jansen, A. N. An All-Organic Non-aqueous Lithium-Ion Redox Flow Battery Adv. Energy Mater. 2012, 2 (11) 1390– 1396 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201200322
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      85
      An all-organic non-aqueous lithium-ion redox flow battery
      Brushett, Fikile R.; Vaughey, John T.; Jansen, Andrew N.
      Advanced Energy Materials (2012), 2 (11), 1390-1396CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A non-aq. lithium-ion redox flow battery employing org. mols. is proposed and investigated. 2,5-Di-tert-butyl-1,4-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)benzene and a variety of mols. derived from quinoxaline are employed as initial high-potential and low-potential active materials, resp. Electrochem. measurements highlight that the choice of electrolyte and of substituent groups can have a significant impact on redox species performance. The charge-discharge characteristics are investigated in a modified coin-cell configuration. After an initial break-in period, coulombic and energy efficiencies for this unoptimized system are ∼70% and ∼37%, resp., with major charge and discharge plateaus between 1.8-2.4 V and 1.7-1.3 V, resp., for 30 cycles. Performance enhancements are expected with improvements in cell design and materials processing.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhsleru73E&md5=265e83f8a61564f28e61e7e352666cf8

      Zhang, L.; Zhang, Z.; Redfern, P. C.; Curtiss, L. A.; Amine, K. Molecular engineering towards safer lithium-ion batteries: a highly stable and compatible redox shuttle for overcharge protection Energy Environ. Sci. 2012, 5 (8) 8204– 8207 DOI: 10.1039/c2ee21977h
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      86
      Molecular engineering towards safer lithium-ion batteries: a highly stable and compatible redox shuttle for overcharge protection
      Zhang, Lu; Zhang, Zhengcheng; Redfern, Paul C.; Curtiss, Larry A.; Amine, Khalil
      Energy & Environmental Science (2012), 5 (8), 8204-8207CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Overcharge abuse is one of the most common and dangerous safety issues with state-of-the-art lithium-ion batteries. Thus, incorporation of overcharge prevention into the lithium-ion battery pack is key to its practical application. Redox shuttle mols. that can be reversibly oxidized and reduced at specific potentials (redox potential) provide an effective and economic method to prevent overcharge abuse for lithium-ion batteries. We have developed a novel oligo(ethylene glycol)-functionalized redox shuttle, 2,5-di-tert-butyl-1,4-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)benzene (DBBB), that is not only capable of providing efficient and long-lasting overcharge protection to lithium-ion batteries (capable of withstanding over 180 cycles of 100% overcharge at the C/2 rate), but is also compatible with the state-of-the-art lithium-ion cell system. D. functional theory calcns. provided an understanding of the stability properties of this new redox shuttle.

      Radical Compatibility with Nonaqueous Electrolytes and Its Impact on an All-Organic Redox Flow Battery
      Wei, Xiaoliang; Xu, Wu; Huang, Jinhua; Zhang, Lu; Walter, Eric; Lawrence, Chad; Vijayakumar, M.; Henderson, Wesley A.; Liu, Tianbiao; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Li, Bin; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (30), 8684-8687CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Nonaq. redox flow batteries hold the promise of achieving higher energy d. because of the broader voltage window than aq. systems, but their current performance is limited by low redox material concn., cell efficiency, cycling stability, and c.d. The authors report a new nonaq. all-org. flow battery based on high concns. of redox materials, which shows significant, comprehensive improvement in flow battery performance. A mechanistic ESR study reveals that the choice of supporting electrolytes greatly affects the chem. stability of the charged radical species esp. the neg. side radical anion, which dominates the cycling stability of these flow cells. This finding not only increases the fundamental understanding of performance degrdn. in flow batteries using radical-based redox species, but also offers insights toward rational electrolyte optimization for improving the cycling stability of these flow batteries.

      A High-Current, Stable Nonaqueous Organic Redox Flow Battery
      Wei, Xiaoliang; Duan, Wentao; Huang, Jinhua; Zhang, Lu; Li, Bin; Reed, David; Xu, Wu; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
      ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (4), 705-711CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      Nonaq. redox flow batteries are promising in pursuit of high energy d. storage systems owing to the broad voltage windows ( > 2 V) but currently are facing key challenges such as limited cyclability and rate performance. To address these tech. hurdles, here the authors report the nonaq. org. flow battery chem. based on N-methylphthalimide anolyte and 2,5-di-tert-butyl-1-methoxy-4-[2'-methoxyethoxy]benzene catholyte, which harvests a theor. cell voltage of 2.30 V. The redox flow chem. exhibits excellent cycling stability under both cyclic voltammetry and flow cell tests upon repeated cycling. Daramic and Celgard porous separators are evaluated in this org. flow battery, which enable the cells to be operated at greatly improved current densities ≤50 mA/cm2 compared to those of other nonaq. flow systems. The stable cyclability and high-current operations of the org. flow battery system represent significant progress in the development of promising nonaq. flow batteries.

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      91
      A subtractive approach to molecular engineering of dimethoxybenzene-based redox materials for non-aqueous flow batteries
      Huang, Jinhua; Su, Liang; Kowalski, Jeffrey A.; Barton, John L.; Ferrandon, Magali; Burrell, Anthony K.; Brushett, Fikile R.; Zhang, Lu
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2015), 3 (29), 14971-14976CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The development of new high capacity redox active materials is key to realizing the potential of non-aq. redox flow batteries (RFBs). In this paper, a series of substituted 1,4-dimethoxybenzene based redox active mols. have been developed via a subtractive design approach. Five mols. have been proposed and developed by removing or reducing the bulky substituent groups of DBBB (2,5-di-tert-butyl-1,4-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)benzene), a successful overcharge protection material for lithium-ion batteries. Of these derivs., 2,3-dimethyl-1,4-dimethoxybenzene (23DDB) and 2,5-dimethyl-1,4-dimethoxybenzene (25DDB) are particularly promising as they demonstrate favorable electrochem. characteristics at gravimetric capacities (161 mA h g-1) that approach the stability limit of chem. reversible dimethoxybenzene based structures. Diffusivity, soly., and galvanostatic cycling results indicate that both 23DDB and 25DDB mols. have promise for non-aq. RFBs.

      Huang, J.; Pan, B.; Duan, W.; Wei, X.; Assary, R. S.; Su, L.; Brushett, F. R.; Cheng, L.; Liao, C.; Ferrandon, M. S.; Wang, W.; Zhang, Z.; Burrell, A. K.; Curtiss, L. A.; Shkrob, I.       92
      The lightest organic radical cation for charge storage in redox flow batteries
      Huang, Jinhua; Pan, Baofei; Duan, Wentao; Wei, Xiaoliang; Assary, Rajeev S.; Su, Liang; Brushett, Fikile R.; Cheng, Lei; Liao, Chen; Ferrandon, Magali S.; Wang, Wei; Zhang, Zhengcheng; Burrell, Anthony K.; Curtiss, Larry A.; Shkrob, Ilya A.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Zhang, Lu
      Scientific Reports (2016), 6 (), 32102CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
      In advanced elec. grids of the future, electrochem. rechargeable fluids of high energy d. will capture the power generated from intermittent sources like solar and wind. To meet this outstanding technol. demand there is a need to understand the fundamental limits and interplay of electrochem. potential, stability, and soly. in low-wt. redox-active mols. By generating a combinatorial set of 1,4-dimethoxybenzene derivs. with different arrangements of substituents, we discovered a minimalistic structure that combines exceptional long-term stability in its oxidized form and a record-breaking intrinsic capacity of 161 mAh/g. The nonaq. redox flow battery has been demonstrated that uses this mol. as a catholyte material and operated stably for 100 charge/discharge cycles. The obsd. stability trends are rationalized by mechanistic considerations of the reaction pathways.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsVantb3K&md5=55eea41756c96a0f74d8b1ad5be6bc54

      Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Yang, B.; Murali, A.; Nirmalchandar, A.; Prakash, G. K. S.; Narayanan, S. R. A New Michael-Reaction-Resistant Benzoquinone for Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries J. Electrochem. Soc. 2017, 164 (4) A600– A607 DOI: 10.1149/2.0351704jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      93
      A New Michael-Reaction-Resistant Benzoquinone for Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries
      Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Krishnamoorthy, Sankarganesh; Yang, Bo; Murali, Advaith; Nirmalchandar, Archith; Prakash, G. K. Surya; Narayanan, S. R.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2017), 164 (4), A600-A607CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      The synthesis, characterization and properties are reported of 3,6-dihydroxy-2,4-dimethylbenzenesulfonic acid (DHDMBS) as a new pos. side electrolyte material for aq. org. redox flow batteries (ORBAT). This material is synthesized in pure form in high yield and its structure is confirmed. It was detd. that the std. redn. potential, the rate const. of the redox reaction, and the diffusion coeff. are ideally suited for use in ORBAT. Specifically, DHDMBS overcomes the major issue of Michael reaction with water faced with 4,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,3-disulfonic acid (BQDS) and similar unsubstituted benzoquinones in the selection of pos. electrolyte materials. The DHDMBS can be synthesized relatively inexpensively. The chem. stability is demonstrated of DHDMBS to repeated electrochem. cycling through NMR and electrochem. studies proving the absence of products of the Michael reaction. A flow cell with DHDMBS and anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid has now been shown to operate close to 100% coulombic efficiency for over 25 cycles when continuously cycled at 100 mA/cm2, and can sustain current densities as high as 500 mA/cm2 without noticeable chem. degrdn. However, there was a slow decrease in the capacity of the flow cell attributable to the crossover of DHDMBS from the pos. side of the cell. Thus, the present study has shown DHDMBS as a promising candidate for the pos. side material for an all-org. aq. redox flow battery in acidic media, and the future efforts will focus on understanding the crossover of DHDMBS and the effects of long-term cycling.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXktlGqsL8%253D&md5=28a87d3dfcaeacc9a68da412239067fa
    94. 94
      Wang, W.; Xu, W.; Cosimbescu, L.; Choi, D.; Li, L.; Yang, Z. G. Anthraquinone with tailored structure for a nonaqueous metal-organic redox flow battery Chem. Commun. 2012, 48 (53) 6669– 6671 DOI: 10.1039/c2cc32466k
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Anthraquinone with tailored structure for a nonaqueous metal-organic redox flow battery
      Wang, Wei; Xu, Wu; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Choi, Daiwon; Li, Liyu; Yang, Zhenguo
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (53), 6669-6671CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A nonaq., hybrid metal-org. redox flow battery based on a tailored anthraquinone structure has an energy efficiency of ∼82% and a sp. discharge energy d. similar to those of aq. redox flow batteries, which is due to the improved soly. of anthraquinone in supporting electrolytes.

    95. 95
      Carney, T. J.; Collins, S. J.; Moore, J. S.; Brushett, F. R. Concentration-Dependent Dimerization of Anthraquinone Disulfonic Acid and Its Impact on Charge Storage Chem. Mater. 2017, 29 (11) 4801– 4810 DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.7b00616
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      95
      Concentration-Dependent Dimerization of Anthraquinone Disulfonic Acid and Its Impact on Charge Storage
      Carney, Thomas J.; Collins, Steven J.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Brushett, Fikile R.
      Chemistry of Materials (2017), 29 (11), 4801-4810CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      9,10-Anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) is considered a benchmark active material for aq. org. redox flow batteries. At low concn., AQDS demonstrates 2-electron transfer at near ideal electrochem. reversibility; however, at higher concn., AQDS displays more complex behavior presumably due to the emergence of intermol. reactions. Here, the authors systematically examine the electrochem. and phys. properties of AQDS solns. using a suite of electrochem., anal., and spectroscopic techniques. Depending on the AQDS pretreatment, concn., soln. pH, and electrolyte compn., coupled chem. and electrochem. reactions lead to different charge storage capabilities. To elucidate the underlying cause of these differences, the authors performed various pre-treatments of AQDS, examd. chem. speciation by NMR, and studied the corresponding electrochem. properties through cyclic voltammetry and bulk electrolysis. In all cases, reversible intermol. dimerization was detected at soln. concns. >10 mM. Also, the charge state of the formed dimers was dependent on the AQDS pretreatment and the soln. pH. Under acidic conditions, 1.5 electrons per mol. of AQDS were reversibly accessible, whereas under buffered mild-alk. conditions, only one electron per mol. of AQDS was accessible. Because of insufficient p concn., AQDS did not cycle reversibly in unbuffered neutral electrolyte. Even when employing chem. oxidants during a chem. titrn., charge storage of 2 electrons per mol. could not be realized. The authors hypothesize that adduct formation between AQDS and CO2, along with soln. pH, play important roles in the charge accessibility.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXotVGmsLw%253D&md5=9136a3dc58d7b524bd9ca74e62935a3e

      [Crossref], Google Scholar

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      98
      Alkaline quinone flow battery
      Lin, Kaixiang; Chen, Qing; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Tong, Liuchuan; Kim, Sang Bok; Eisenach, Louise; Valle, Alvaro W.; Hardee, David; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.; Marshak, Michael P.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2015), 349 (6255), 1529-1532CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Storage of photovoltaic and wind electricity in batteries could solve the mismatch problem between the intermittent supply of these renewable resources and variable demand. Flow batteries permit more economical long-duration discharge than solid-electrode batteries by using liq. electrolytes stored outside of the battery. We report an alk. flow battery based on redox-active org. mols. that are composed entirely of Earth-abundant elements and are nontoxic, nonflammable, and safe for use in residential and com. environments. The battery operates efficiently with high power d. near room temp. These results demonstrate the stability and performance of redox-active org. mols. in alk. flow batteries, potentially enabling cost-effective stationary storage of renewable energy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFCrtbjN&md5=03e98c7de27aa2f1cfe9c71b6e9823bc
    99. 99
      Yang, B.; Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Wang, F.; Surya Prakash, G. K.; Narayanan, S. R. An Inexpensive Aqueous Flow Battery for Large-Scale Electrical Energy Storage Based on Water-Soluble Organic Redox Couples J. Electrochem. Soc. 2014, 161 (9) A1371– A1380 DOI: 10.1149/2.1001409jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      99
      An Inexpensive Aqueous Flow Battery for Large-Scale Electrical Energy Storage Based on Water-Soluble Organic Redox Couples
      Yang, Bo; Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Wang, Fang; Surya Prakash, G. K.; Narayanan, S. R.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2014), 161 (9), A1371-A1380CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      We introduce a novel Org. Redox Flow Battery (ORBAT), for meeting the demanding requirements of cost, eco-friendliness, and durability for large-scale energy storage. ORBAT employs two different water-sol. org. redox couples on the pos. and neg. side of a flow battery. Redox couples such as quinones are particularly attractive for this application. No precious metal catalyst is needed because of the fast proton-coupled electron transfer processes. Furthermore, in acid media, the quinones exhibit good chem. stability. These properties render quinone-based redox couples very attractive for high-efficiency metal-free rechargeable batteries. We demonstrate the rechargeability of ORBAT with anthraquinone-2-sulfonic acid or anthraquinone-2,6-disulfonic acid on the neg. side, and 1,2-dihydrobenzoquinone-3,5-disulfonic acid on the pos. side. The ORBAT cell uses a membrane-electrode assembly configuration similar to that used in polymer electrolyte fuel cells. Such a battery can be charged and discharged multiple times at high faradaic efficiency without any noticeable degrdn. of performance. We show that soly. and mass transport properties of the reactants and products are paramount to achieving high current densities and high efficiency. The ORBAT configuration presents a unique opportunity for developing an inexpensive and sustainable metal-free rechargeable battery for large-scale elec. energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFOnsrnO&md5=1bd4bc1ac4fccd7b9d18ea3dce981eb9
    100. 100
      Yang, B.; Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Murali, A.; Prakash, G. K. S.; Narayanan, S. R. High-Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery with Quinone-Based Redox Couples at Both Electrodes J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (7) A1442– A1449 DOI: 10.1149/2.1371607jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      100
      High-Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery with Quinone-Based Redox Couples at Both Electrodes
      Yang, Bo; Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Krishnamoorthy, Sankarganesh; Murali, Advaith; Prakash, G. K. Surya; Narayanan, S. R.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (7), A1442-A1449CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      The authors demonstrated the repeated cycling of a redox flow cell based on H2O-sol. org. redox couples (ORBAT) at high voltage efficiency, coulombic efficiency and power d. These cells were successfully operated with 4,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,3-disulfonic acid (BQDS) at the pos. electrode and anthraquinone-2,6-disulfonic acid (AQDS) at the neg. electrode. Redn. of the voltage losses arising from mass transport limitations, and understanding of the chem. transformations of BQDS during charging led to these improvements in performance. The specific advances reported here include the use of org. redox couples in the free-acid form, improvements to the flow field configuration, and novel high-surface-area graphite-felt electrode structures. The authors have identified various steps in the chem. and electrochem. transformations of BQDS during the 1st few cycles. Also the crossover of the reactants through the membrane was not significant. The performance improvements and new understanding presented here will hasten the development of ORBAT as an inexpensive and sustainable soln. for large-scale elec. energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XnvFWisL8%253D&md5=e0a2a6f78533a4ea712449f1d7f07a47

      Lalevee, J.; Allonas, X.; Jacques, P. Struct.: THEOCHEM 2006, 767 (1–3) 143– 147 DOI: 10.1016/j.theochem.2006.05.054
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      101
      Electronic distribution and solvatochromism investigation of a model radical (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine N-oxyl: tempo) through TD-DFT calculations including PCM solvation
      Lalevee, J.; Allonas, X.; Jacques, P.
      Journal of Molecular Structure: THEOCHEM (2006), 767 (1-3), 143-147CODEN: THEODJ; ISSN:0166-1280. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The solvatochromism of the 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine N-oxyl radical (TEMPO) visible band (n→π*) is reported. When the solvent polarity increases, a blue shift is obsd. that is typical for a n→π* transition. This behavior is well accounted for by time-dependent d. functional theory (TD-DFT) including polarizable continuum model (PCM) solvation in non-specific solvents. However, the agreement between the expts. and the computations for hydroxylic solvents is not straightforward at all. Addnl., valuable information on the electronic/spin distributions and their solvent dependence are presented, a key point for discussing the chem. reactivity of radicals.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Wei, X.; Xu, W.; Vijayakumar, M.; Cosimbescu, L.; Liu, T.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. TEMPO-Based Catholyte for High-Energy Density Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries Adv. Mater. 2014, 26 (45) 7649– 7653 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201403746
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      102
      TEMPO-Based Catholyte for High-Energy Density Non-aqueous Redox Flow Batteries
      Wei, Xiaoliang; Xu, Wu; Vijayakumar, Murugesan; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Liu, Tianbiao; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2014), 26 (45), 7649-7653CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A TEMPO-based non-aq. electrolyte has been developed and evaluated in a hybrid Li|TEMPO redox-flow battery. The TEMPO redox material offers a high redox potential (3.5 V vs. Li/Li+) and a high soly. (2.0 M in the supporting LiPF6 electrolyte), which are key parameters for an electrolyte to achieve high energy d. in flow batteries. The hybrid Li/graphite anode and the FEC SEI-stabilizing additive used to protect the Li anode led to good cyclability for the Li|TEMPO flow batteries at 0.1 M and 0.8 M TEMPO concns. At 2.0 M TEMPO, the Li|TEMPO flow cell delivers an EE of about 70% and a discharge volumetric energy d. of 126 W-h L-1 that exceeds most state-of-the-art aq. and non-aq. flow batteries. Flow battery tests of TEMPO-based electrolytes have demonstrated potential for offering high energy d. - it is also adaptable to other non-aq. redox flow chemistries, for example, as the catholyte in an all-org. flow battery. In addn., we demonstrated that ESR can be used to est. the SOC for nonaq. flow batteries when redox species with unpaired electrons are present.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXitVCitb3P&md5=ba24a1bb387b7321aca56d02e35273be
