      Electrochemical Properties of an All-Organic Redox Flow Battery Using 2,2,6,6-Tetramethyl-1-Piperidinyloxy and N-Methylphthalimide
      Li, Zhen; Li, Sha; Liu, Suqin; Huang, Kelong; Fang, Dong; Wang, Fengchao; Peng, Sui
      Electrochemical and Solid-State Letters (2011), 14 (12), A171-A173CODEN: ESLEF6; ISSN:1099-0062. (Electrochemical Society)
      A novel all-org. redox flow battery employing 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy/NaClO4/acetonitrile and N-Methyl- phthalimide/NaClO4/acetonitrile as catholyte and anolyte, resp., is investigated by electrochem. measurements. The quasi-reversible and stable redox reactions are tested by cycle voltammetry. The diffusion coeff. of 0.02 M 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy and 0.02 M N-Methylphthalimide in the supporting electrolyte are all in the range of 0.7-1.1× 10-5 cm2·s-1 at room temp. Stable charge-discharge curves and high coulombic efficiency (90%) for the first 20 cycles are obtained through charge-discharge test.

      104
      Electrochemical properties of a non-aqueous redox battery with all-organic redox couples
      Park, Se-Kook; Shim, Joonmok; Yang, JungHoon; Shin, Kyoung-Hee; Jin, Chang-Soo; Lee, Bum Suk; Lee, Young-Seak; Jeon, Jae-Deok
      Electrochemistry Communications (2015), 59 (), 68-71CODEN: ECCMF9; ISSN:1388-2481. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A novel all-org. redox cell employing 4-Oxo 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy (4-Oxo TEMPO) (as a catholyte) and (1S)-(+)-Camphorquinone (as an anolyte) is investigated through electrochem. measurements. From cyclic voltammetry tests, it is confirmed that electrochem. reversible redox processes of 4-Oxo TEMPO and (1S)-(+)-Camphorquinone occur at 0.48 V and - 1.64 V (vs. Ag/Ag+), resp. A non-aq. redox battery with these redox couples can yield an estd. open circuit potential of 2.12 V at a 50% state of charge. The charge-discharge performance is assessed with an inhouse designed non-flow single cell. Coulombic and energy efficiencies are 80.3% and 71.3%, resp.

      Takechi, K.; Kato, Y.; Hase, Y. A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Based on a Solvate Ionic Liquid for Rechargeable Flow Batteries Adv. Mater. 2015, 27 (15) 2501– 2506 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201405840
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      105
      A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Based on a Solvate Ionic Liquid for Rechargeable Flow Batteries
      Takechi, Kensuke; Kato, Yuichi; Hase, Yoko
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2015), 27 (15), 2501-2506CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A new class of catholyte employing a stabilized supercooled liq. through the combination of a specific org. radical (MT) and plasticizing Li salt (LT) is presented. The catholyte has the unique feature of forming an MT-LT coupled structure to stabilize its supercooled state over a wide temp. range and can be characterized as a "solvated ionic liq.". The addn. of water to this supercooled, liq. does not damage its unique feature of having one of the highest energy densities as a pure liq. using org. redox compd. but improves the parameters required for battery applications, such as viscosity and cond. The performance of a battery with a Li-ion conducting architecture has proved this battery's potential for high-energy-d. flow battery applications because the supercooled liq. consists of environmentally friendly compds. (noncorrosive and heavy-metal-free). This battery has facile scalability and high adaptability for actual flowing architectures. The simple mol. structure of MT and facile prepn. of the catholyte also give a large potential to reduce prodn. costs. The strategy for creating a high-energy-d. catholyte can be used to prep. other org. redox-active liqs. and will be reported.

      Duan, W.; Vemuri, R. S.; Milshtein, J. D.; Laramie, S.; Dmello, R. D.; Huang, J.; Zhang, L.; Hu, D.; Vijayakumar, M.; Wang, W.; Liu, J.; Darling, R. M.; Thompson, L.; Smith, K.; Moore, J. S.; Brushett, F. R.; Wei, X. A symmetric organic-based nonaqueous redox flow battery and its state of charge diagnostics by FTIR J. Mater. Chem. A 2016, 4 (15) 5448– 5456 DOI: 10.1039/C6TA01177B
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      A symmetric organic-based nonaqueous redox flow battery and its state of charge diagnostics by FTIR
      Duan, Wentao; Vemuri, Rama S.; Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Laramie, Sydney; Dmello, Rylan D.; Huang, Jinhua; Zhang, Lu; Hu, Dehong; Vijayakumar, M.; Wang, Wei; Liu, Jun; Darling, Robert M.; Thompson, Levi; Smith, Kyle; Moore, Jeffery S.; Brushett, Fikile R.; Wei, Xiaoliang
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2016), 4 (15), 5448-5456CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Redox flow batteries have shown outstanding promise for grid-scale energy storage to promote utilization of renewable energy and improve grid stability. Nonaq. battery systems can potentially achieve high energy d. because of their broad voltage window. In this paper, we report a new org. redox-active material for use in a nonaq. redox flow battery, 2-phenyl-4,4,5,5-tetramethylimidazoline-1-oxyl-3-oxide (PTIO) that has high soly. (>2.6 M) in org. solvents. PTIO exhibits electrochem. reversible disproportionation reactions and thus can serve as both anolyte and catholyte redox materials in a sym. flow cell. The PTIO flow battery has a moderate cell voltage of ∼1.7 V and shows good cyclability under both cyclic voltammetry and flow cell conditions. Moreover, we demonstrate that FTIR can offer accurate estn. of the PTIO concn. in electrolytes and det. the state of charge of the PTIO flow cell, suggesting FTIR as a powerful online battery status sensor. This study is expected to inspire more insights in this under-addressed area of state of charge anal. aiming at operational safety and reliability of flow batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XktVaktLY%253D&md5=345132f3c0ba15bab0ddfcc0a5bdb2f1

      Janoschka, T.; Martin, N.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. An Aqueous Redox-Flow Battery with High Capacity and Power: The TEMPTMA/MV System Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55 (46) 14427– 14430 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201606472
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      107
      Aqueous Redox-Flow Battery with High Capacity and Power: The TEMPTMA/MV System
      Janoschka, Tobias; Martin, Norbert; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (46), 14427-14430CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Redox-flow batteries (RFB) can easily store large amts. of elec. energy and thereby mitigate the fluctuating output of renewable power plants. They are widely discussed as energy-storage solns. for wind and solar farms to improve the stability of the elec. grid. Most common RFB concepts are based on strongly acidic metal-salt solns. or poorly performing orgs. Herein the authors present a battery which employs the highly sol. N,N,N-2,2,6,6-heptamethylpiperidinyl oxy-4-NH4Cl (TEMPTMA) and the viologen deriv. N,N'-dimethyl-4,4-bipyridinium dichloride (MV) in a simple and safe aq. soln. as redox-active materials. The resulting battery using these electrolyte solns. has capacities of 54 A-h L-1, giving a total energy d. of 38 Wh L-1 at a cell voltage of 1.4 V. With peak current densities of up to 200 mA cm-2 the TEMPTMA/MV system is a suitable candidate for compact high-capacity and high-power applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1yktLbO&md5=4b1872b866b8fe09cf4f41b3182046ad

      Winsberg, J.; Stolze, C.; Schwenke, A.; Muench, S.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. Aqueous 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl Catholytes for a High-Capacity and High Current Density Oxygen-Insensitive Hybrid-Flow Battery ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (2) 411– 416 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.6b00655
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      108
      Aqueous 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl Catholytes for a High-Capacity and High Current Density Oxygen-Insensitive Hybrid-Flow Battery
      Winsberg, Jan; Stolze, Christian; Schwenke, Almut; Muench, Simon; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
      ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (2), 411-416CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      Hybrid-flow batteries are a suitable storage technol. for green electricity generated by renewable sources such as wind power and solar energy. Redox-active org. compds. have recently been investigated to improve the traditional metal- and halogen-based technologies. Here the utilization is reported of a 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) deriv. that is in particular designed for application in semiorg. zinc hybrid-flow batteries. The TEMPO deriv. is synthesized and electrochem. characterized via cyclic voltammetry and rotating disc electrode measurements. This deriv. features a high soly. in aq. electrolytes; thus, volumetric capacities > 20 AhL-1 are achieved. The fabricated hybrid-flow batteries feature over 1100 consecutive charge-discharge cycles at const. capacity retention, and current densities up to 80 mAcm-2 are applied.

      Duan, W.; Vemuri, R. S.; Hu, D.; Yang, Z.; Wei, X. A Protocol for Electrochemical Evaluations and State of Charge Diagnostics of a Symmetric Organic Redox Flow Battery J. Visualized Exp. 2017, 120) e55171 DOI: 10.3791/55171

    111. 111
      Potash, R. A.; McKone, J. R.; Conte, S.; Abruña, H. D. On the Benefits of a Symmetric Redox Flow Battery J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (3) A338– A344 DOI: 10.1149/2.0971602jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      111
      On the Benefits of a Symmetric Redox Flow Battery
      Potash, Rebecca A.; McKone, James R.; Conte, Sean; Abruena, Hector D.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (3), A338-A344CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are of interest for large-scale energy storage, but implementation has been challenged by their low energy d., high complexity, high cost, and insufficient lifetime due to several types of irreversible losses in the electrolyte. To address the issue of system complexity and irreversible losses, we have undertaken a detailed anal. of the concept of the sym. redox flow battery, or SRFB, which relies on a single parent mol. as the charge storage species in both the pos. and neg. electrode reactions. We elaborate on the operating principles and advantages of a SRFB and report the salient electrochem. properties of a class of org. mols., diaminoanthraquinones (DAAQs) as promising candidates for use in SRFB redox electrolytes. Modeling of various modes of operation for SRFBs are presented along with an example of an operational, lab.-scale SRFB based on a DAAQ system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xos1WntA%253D%253D&md5=6075a88831c4d2449fe9f6eb8cb5205d
    112. 112
      Milshtein, J. D.; Su, L.; Liou, C.; Badel, A. F.; Brushett, F. R. Voltammetry study of quinoxaline in aqueous electrolytes Electrochim. Acta 2015, 180, 695– 704 DOI: 10.1016/j.electacta.2015.07.063
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      112
      Voltammetry study of quinoxaline in aqueous electrolytes
      Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Su, Liang; Liou, Catherine; Badel, Andres F.; Brushett, Fikile R.
      Electrochimica Acta (2015), 180 (), 695-704CODEN: ELCAAV; ISSN:0013-4686. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Org. compds. have recently received considerable attention as active materials in redox flow batteries (RFBs) due to their good electrochem. reversibility, high theor. energy densities, and promise for low cost prodn. Until now, org. active material candidates for aq. RFBs have been limited to the quinone family, a set of arom.-derived org. mols., distinguished by an even no. of ketone (R-C(=O)-R') groups. This work aims to elucidate and optimize the electrochem. behavior of quinoxaline, an org. mol. consisting of fused benzene and pyrazine rings, in aq. electrolytes. More than 30 electrolytes are screened by cyclic voltammetry, and the five most promising electrolytes are investigated further using rotating disk voltammetry. Electrochem. behavior of quinoxaline shows pH dependent thermodn. and reaction mechanisms, while chloride-contg. supporting electrolytes greatly enhance soly. This study sheds light on the promising characteristics of quinoxaline as a low potential compd. for aq. RFBs; quinoxaline has a redox potential of E° ≈ -0.02 V vs. RHE, is sol. up to ∼4.5 M in water, exhibits a two-electron transfer capability, and possesses a low mol. wt. (130.15 g mol-1), resulting in a theor. capacity of 410 mAh g-1.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFertLbE&md5=9ebec342c451af5c3e2280f97deaada7

      Sevov, C. S.; Brooner, R. E. M.; Chenard, E.; Assary, R. S.; Moore, J. S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, J.; Sanford, M. S. Evolutionary Design of Low Molecular Weight Organic Anolyte Materials for Applications in Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2015, 137 (45) 14465– 14472 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.5b09572
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      113
      Evolutionary Design of Low Molecular Weight Organic Anolyte Materials for Applications in Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
      Sevov, Christo S.; Brooner, Rachel E. M.; Chenard, Etienne; Assary, Rajeev S.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, Joaquin; Sanford, Melanie S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (45), 14465-14472CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The integration of renewable energy sources into the elec. grid requires low-cost energy storage systems that mediate the variable and intermittent flux of energy assocd. with most renewables. Nonaq. redox-flow batteries have emerged as a promising technol. for grid-scale energy storage applications. Because the cost of the system scales with mass, the electroactive materials must have a low equiv. wt. (ideally 150 g/(mol·e-) or less), and must function with low mol. wt. supporting electrolytes such as LiBF4. However, sol. anolyte materials that undergo reversible redox processes in the presence of Li-ion supports are rare. We report the evolutionary design of a series of pyridine-based anolyte materials that exhibit up to two reversible redox couples at low potentials in the presence of Li-ion supporting electrolytes. A combination of cyclic voltammetry of anolyte candidates and independent synthesis of their corresponding charged-states was performed to rapidly screen for the most promising candidates. Results of this workflow provided evidence for possible decompn. pathways of first-generation materials and guided synthetic modifications to improve the stability of anolyte materials under the targeted conditions. This iterative process led to the identification of a promising anolyte material, N-Me 4-acetylpyridinium tetrafluoroborate. This compd. is sol. in nonaq. solvents, is prepd. in a single synthetic step, has a low equiv. wt. of 111 g/(mol·e-), and undergoes two reversible 1e- redns. in the presence of LiBF4 to form reduced products that are stable over days in soln.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVSktLfI&md5=de98cc11fb73aa3b765efb4ace23832b
    114. 114
      Sevov, C. S.; Hickey, D. P.; Cook, M. E.; Robinson, S. G.; Barnett, S.; Minteer, S. D.; Sigman, M. S.; Sanford, M. S. Physical Organic Approach to Persistent, Cyclable, Low-Potential Electrolytes for Flow Battery Applications J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139 (8) 2924– 2927 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.7b00147
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      114
      Physical Organic Approach to Persistent, Cyclable, Low-Potential Electrolytes for Flow Battery Applications
      Sevov, Christo S.; Hickey, David P.; Cook, Monique E.; Robinson, Sophia G.; Barnett, Shoshanna; Minteer, Shelley D.; Sigman, Matthew S.; Sanford, Melanie S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (8), 2924-2927CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The deployment of nonaq. redox flow batteries for grid-scale energy storage has been impeded by a lack of electrolytes that undergo redox events at as low (anolyte) or high (catholyte) potentials as possible while exhibiting the stability and cycling lifetimes necessary for a battery device. Herein, we report a new approach to electrolyte design that uses phys. org. tools for the predictive targeting of electrolytes that possess this combination of properties. We apply this approach to the identification of a new pyridinium-based anolyte that undergoes 1e- electrochem. charge-discharge cycling at low potential (-1.21 V vs Fc/Fc+) to a 95% state-of-charge without detectable capacity loss after 200 cycles.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXivVyrsLg%253D&md5=eb9ae6a6d73d951f3085bf06708b75c8

      Kaur, A. P.; Holubowitch, N. E.; Ergun, S.; Elliott, C. F.; Odom, S. A. A Highly Soluble Organic Catholyte for Non-Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries Energy Technol. 2015, 3 (5) 476– 480 DOI: 10.1002/ente.201500020
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      115
      A Highly Soluble Organic Catholyte for Non-Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries
      Kaur, Aman Preet; Holubowitch, Nicolas E.; Ergun, Selin; Elliott, Corrine F.; Odom, Susan A.
      Energy Technology (Weinheim, Germany) (2015), 3 (5), 476-480CODEN: ETNEFN; ISSN:2194-4296. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A phenothiazine deriv. with high soly. in carbonate solvents contg. lithium salts showed extensive overcharge protection and, as a result, has been evaluated as a catholyte for non-aq. redox flow batteries. We report the testing of 3,7-bis(trifluoromethyl)-N-ethylphenothiazine as a catholyte and 2,3,6-trimethylquinoxaline as the anolyte in redox flow batteries contg. 0.05, 0.15, and 0.35 M active material and found the longest capacity retention over about 60 cycles at 0.15 M. To our knowledge, this is the most sol. catholyte candidate with a robust radical cation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXosVCiurw%253D&md5=5f35c2c913da2684fd3fa29257b7c624
    116. 116
      Milshtein, J. D.; Kaur, A. P.; Casselman, M. D.; Kowalski, J. A.; Modekrutti, S.; Zhang, P. L.; Harsha Attanayake, N.; Elliott, C. F.; Parkin, S. R.; Risko, C.; Brushett, F. R.; Odom, S. A. High current density, long duration cycling of soluble organic active species for non-aqueous redox flow batteries Energy Environ. Sci. 2016, 9 (11) 3531– 3543 DOI: 10.1039/C6EE02027E
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      116
      High current density, long duration cycling of soluble organic active species for non-aqueous redox flow batteries
      Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Kaur, Aman Preet; Casselman, Matthew D.; Kowalski, Jeffrey A.; Modekrutti, Subrahmanyam; Zhang, Peter L.; Harsha Attanayake, N.; Elliott, Corrine F.; Parkin, Sean R.; Risko, Chad; Brushett, Fikile R.; Odom, Susan A.
      Energy & Environmental Science (2016), 9 (11), 3531-3543CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Non-aq. redox flow batteries (NAqRFBs) employing redox-active org. mols. show promise to meet requirements for grid energy storage. Here, we combine the rational design of org. mols. with flow cell engineering to boost NAqRFB performance. We synthesize two highly sol. phenothiazine derivs., N-(2-methoxyethyl)phenothiazine (MEPT) and N-[2-(2-methoxyethoxy)ethyl]phenothiazine (MEEPT), via a one-step synthesis from inexpensive precursors. Synthesis and isolation of the radical-cation salts permit UV-vis decay studies that illustrate the high stability of these open-shell species. Cyclic voltammetry and bulk electrolysis expts. reveal the promising electrochem. properties of MEPT and MEEPT under dil. conditions. A high performance non-aq. flow cell, employing interdigitated flow fields and carbon paper electrodes, is engineered and demonstrated; polarization and impedance studies quantify the cell's low area-specific resistance (3.2-3.3 Ω cm2). We combine the most sol. deriv., MEEPT, and its tetrafluoroborate radical-cation salt in the flow cell for sym. cycling, evincing a c.d. of 100 mA cm-2 with undetectable capacity fade over 100 cycles. This coincident high c.d. and capacity retention is unprecedented in NAqRFB literature.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsFWlsrrI&md5=51155c9921b6ba9da123d44542a8675b

      Lin, K.; Gomez-Bombarelli, R.; Beh, E. S.; Tong, L.; Chen, Q.; Valle, A.; Aspuru-Guzik, A.; Aziz, M. J.; Gordon, R. G. A redox-flow battery with an alloxazine-based organic electrolyte Nat. Energy 2016, 1, 16102 DOI: 10.1038/nenergy.2016.102
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      117
      A redox-flow battery with an alloxazine-based organic electrolyte
      Lin, Kaixiang; Gomez-Bombarelli, Rafael; Beh, Eugene S.; Tong, Liuchuan; Chen, Qing; Valle, Alvaro; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Aziz, Michael J.; Gordon, Roy G.
      Nature Energy (2016), 1 (9), 16102CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Redox-flow batteries (RFBs) can store large amts. of elec. energy from variable sources, such as solar and wind. Recently, redox-active org. mols. in aq. RFBs have drawn substantial attention due to their rapid kinetics and low membrane crossover rates. Drawing inspiration from nature, here we report a high-performance aq. RFB utilizing an org. redox compd., alloxazine, which is a tautomer of the isoalloxazine backbone of vitamin B2. It can be synthesized in high yield at room temp. by single-step coupling of inexpensive o-phenylenediamine derivs. and alloxan. The highly alk.-sol. alloxazine 7/8-carboxylic acid produces a RFB exhibiting open-circuit voltage approaching 1.2 V and current efficiency and capacity retention exceeding 99.7% and 99.98% per cycle, resp. Theor. studies indicate that structural modification of alloxazine with electron-donating groups should allow further increases in battery voltage. As an aza-arom. mol. that undergoes reversible redox cycling in aq. electrolyte, alloxazine represents a class of radical-free redox-active orgs. for use in large-scale energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVersrY%253D&md5=1bdb2e213c96396bad489b2404fbc367

      Orita, A.; Verde, M. G.; Sakai, M.; Meng, Y. S. A biomimetic redox flow battery based on flavin mononucleotide Nat. Commun. 2016, 7, 13230 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms13230
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      118
      A biomimetic redox flow battery based on flavin mononucleotide
      Orita, Akihiro; Verde, Michael G.; Sakai, Masanori; Meng, Ying Shirley
      Nature Communications (2016), 7 (), 13230CODEN: NCAOBW; ISSN:2041-1723. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The versatility in design of redox flow batteries makes them apt to efficiently store energy in large-scale applications at low cost. The discovery of inexpensive org. electroactive materials for use in aq. flow battery electrolytes is highly attractive, but is thus far limited. Here we report on a flow battery using an aq. electrolyte based on the sodium salt of FMN. Flavins are highly versatile electroactive mols., which catalyze a multitude of redox reactions in biol. systems. We use nicotinamide (vitamin B3) as a hydrotropic agent to enhance the water soly. of FMN. A redox flow battery using FMN neg. and ferrocyanide pos. electrolytes in strong base shows stable cycling performance, with over 99% capacity retention over the course of 100 cycles. We hypothesize that this is enabled due to the oxidized and reduced forms of FMN-Na being stabilized by resonance structures.

      Yu, J.; Hu, Y.; Pan, F.; Zhang, Z.; Wang, Q.; Li, H.; Huang, X.; Chen, L. A class of liquid anode for rechargeable batteries with ultralong cycle life Nat. Commun. 2017, 8, 14629 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms14629
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      121
      A class of liquid anode for rechargeable batteries with ultralong cycle life
      Yu Juezhi; Hu Yong-Sheng; Zhang Zhizhen; Li Hong; Huang Xuejie; Chen Liquan; Pan Feng; Wang Qing
      Nature communications (2017), 8 (), 14629 ISSN:.
      Low cost, highly efficient and safe devices for energy storage have long been desired in our society. Among these devices, electrochemical batteries with alkali metal anodes have attracted worldwide attention. However, the practical application of such systems is limited by dendrite formation and low cycling efficiency of alkali metals. Here we report a class of liquid anodes fabricated by dissolving sodium metal into a mixed solution of biphenyl and ethers. Such liquid anodes are highly safe and have a low redox potential of 0.09 V versus sodium, exhibiting a high conductivity of 1.2 × 10(-2) S cm(-1). When coupled with polysulfides dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide as the cathode, a battery is demonstrated to sustain over 3,500 cycles without measureable capacity loss at room temperature. This work provides a base for exploring a family of liquid anodes for rechargeable batteries that potentially meet the requirements for grid-scale electrical energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1czjtFagsw%253D%253D&md5=9992cba0c39249795312f1c5884cd6e1

      A metal-free and all-organic redox flow battery with polythiophene as the electroactive species
      Oh, S. H.; Lee, C.-W.; Chun, D. H.; Jeon, J.-D.; Shim, J.; Shin, K. H.; Yang, J. H.
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2014), 2 (47), 19994-19998CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A metal-free and all-org. redox flow battery is proposed and investigated. It employs polythiophene microparticles dispersed in electrolyte solns. as the redox couple and does not depend on limited metal resources. It shows a high cell potential and stable charge/discharge performance with a high energy efficiency of 60.9%.

      Wu, M.; Bhargav, A.; Cui, Y.; Siegel, A.; Agarwal, M.; Ma, Y.; Fu, Y. Highly Reversible Diphenyl Trisulfide Catholyte for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries ACS Energy Lett. 2016, 1 (6) 1221– 1226 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.6b00533
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      123
      Highly Reversible Diphenyl Trisulfide Catholyte for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries
      Wu, Min; Bhargav, Amruth; Cui, Yi; Siegel, Amanda; Agarwal, Mangilal; Ma, Ying; Fu, Yongzhu
      ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (6), 1221-1226CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      Organotrisulfide (RSSSR) is a new class of high-capacity cathode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries. The org. R group can tune the structure and property of organotrisulfide as well as electrochem. performance in batteries. Herein, a nominal di-Ph trisulfide (DPTS, C6H5SSSC6H5) catholyte is reported for rechargeable lithium batteries. Three sulfur atoms allow 4e- storage per mol., affording DPTS with a theor. capacity of 428 mAh g-1. The DPTS catholyte is synthesized from a coupling reaction of di-Ph disulfide (DPDS) and elemental sulfur in liq. electrolyte at 70°. It is found that the DPTS catholyte is a mixt. of DPTS, DPDS, and elemental sulfur in the electrolyte. The lithium cell with the DPTS catholyte delivers an initial specific capacity of 330 mAh g-1DPTS and retains 79% of the initial capacity over 100 cycles at the C/2 rate. The cell delivers an initial discharge specific energy of 751 Wh kg-1DPTS with a high energy efficiency of over 95% at the C/5 rate. The achievable energy d. of the DPTS catholyte (1.0 M) is 158 Wh L-1. This study shows that DPTS is a promising high-capacity cathode material for highly reversible lithium batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVGqsbjO&md5=acce806ed445df8ab75342063ca5f158

      Zhang, H.; Zhang, H.; Li, X.; Mai, Z.; Zhang, J. Nanofiltration (NF) membranes: the next generation separators for all vanadium redox flow batteries (VRBs)? Energy Environ. Sci. 2011, 4 (5) 1676– 1679 DOI: 10.1039/c1ee01117k
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      124
      Nanofiltration (NF) membranes: the next generation separators for all vanadium redox flow batteries (VRBs)
      Zhang, Hongzhang; Zhang, Huamin; Li, Xianfeng; Mai, Zhensheng; Zhang, Jianlu
      Energy & Environmental Science (2011), 4 (5), 1676-1679CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      NF membranes, as an alternative to traditional ion exchange membranes, were first proposed and successfully prepd. for VRBs based on a totally new concept of tuning the vanadium/proton selectivity via pore size exclusion. The results showed that membranes show increasing vanadium ion/proton (V/H) selectivity with decreasing pore size distribution. VRBs assembled with prepd. NF membranes exhibited comparable performance to that of commercialized Nafion. The concept could potentially overcome the traditional restriction from ion exchange membranes and provide much more material options for VRB membranes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Wei, X.; Nie, Z.; Luo, Q.; Li, B.; Chen, B.; Simmons, K.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. Nanoporous Polytetrafl uoroethylene/Silica Composite Separator as a High-Performance All-Vanadium Redox Flow Battery Membrane Adv. Energy Mater. 2013, 3 (9) 1215– 1220 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201201112
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      125
      Nanoporous Polytetrafluoroethylene/Silica Composite Separator as a High-Performance All-Vanadium Redox Flow Battery Membrane
      Wei, Xiaoliang; Nie, Zimin; Luo, Qingtao; Li, Bin; Chen, Baowei; Simmons, Kevin; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
      Advanced Energy Materials (2013), 3 (9), 1215-1220CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A novel low-cost nanoporous polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)/silica composite separator has been prepd. and evaluated for its use in an all-vanadium redox flow battery (VRB). The separator consists of silica particles enmeshed in a PTFE fibril matrix. It possesses unique nanoporous structures with an av. pore size of 38 nm and a porosity of 48%. These pores function as the ion transport channels during redox flow battery operation. This separator provides excellent electrochem. performance in the mixed-acid VRB system. The VRB using this separator delivers impressive energy efficiency, rate capability, and temp. tolerance. In addn., the flow cell using the novel separator also demonstrates an exceptional capacity retention capability over extended cycling, thus offering excellent stability for long-term operation. The characteristics of low cost, excellent electrochem. performance and proven chem. stability afford the PTFE/silica nanoporous separator great potential as a substitute for the Nafion membrane used in VRB applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsVeku7vJ&md5=b2d45fa8a3cd727abcf9cb052dea669c

      Su, L.; Darling, R. M.; Gallagher, K. G.; Xie, W.; Thelen, J. L.; Badel, A. F.; Barton, J. L.; Cheng, K. J.; Balsara, N. P.; Moore, J. S.; Brushett, F. R. An Investigation of the Ionic Conductivity and Species Crossover of Lithiated Nafion 117 in Nonaqueous Electrolytes J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (1) A5253– A5262 DOI: 10.1149/2.03211601jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      128
      An Investigation of the Ionic Conductivity and Species Crossover of Lithiated Nafion 117 in Nonaqueous Electrolytes
      Su, Liang; Darling, Robert M.; Gallagher, Kevin G.; Xie, Wei; Thelen, Jacob L.; Badel, Andres F.; Barton, John L.; Cheng, Kevin J.; Balsara, Nitash P.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Brushett, Fikile R.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5253-A5262CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      Nonaq. redox flow batteries are a fast-growing area of research and development motivated by the need to develop low-cost energy storage systems. The identification of a highly conductive, yet selective membrane, is of paramount importance to enabling such a technol. Herein, we report the swelling behavior, ionic cond., and species crossover of lithiated Nafion 117 membranes immersed in three nonaq. electrolytes (PC, PC : EC, and DMSO). Our results show that solvent vol. fraction within the membrane has the greatest effect on both cond. and crossover. An approx. linear relationship between diffusive crossover of neutral redox species (ferrocene) and the ionic cond. of membrane was obsd. As a secondary effect, the charge on redox species modifies crossover rates in accordance with Donnan exclusion. The selectivity of membrane is derived math. and compared to exptl. results reported here. The relatively low selectivity for lithiated Nafion 117 in nonaq. conditions suggests that new membranes are required for competitive nonaq. redox flow batteries to be realized. Potential design rules are suggested for the future membrane engineering work.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr3P&md5=174ba18899d02b48ba4cbe014c093a5a
    129. 129
      Small, L. J.; Pratt, H. D.; Fujimoto, C. H.; Anderson, T. M. Diels Alder Polyphenylene Anion Exchange Membrane for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (1) A5106– A5111 DOI: 10.1149/2.0141601jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      129
      Diels Alder Polyphenylene Anion Exchange Membrane for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
      Small, Leo J.; Pratt, Harry D., III; Fujimoto, Cy H.; Anderson, Travis M.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5106-A5111CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      Here highly conductive, solvent-resistant anionic Diels Alder polyphenylene (DAPP) membranes were synthesized with three different ionic contents and tested in an ionic liq.-based nonaq. redox flow battery (RFB). These membranes display 3-10× increase in cond. in propylene carbonate compared to some com. available (aq.) anion exchange membranes. The membrane with an ion content of 1.5 meq/g (DAPP1.5) proved too brittle for operation in a RFB, while the membrane with an ion content of 2.5 meq/g (DAPP2.5) allowed excessive movement of solvent and poor electrochem. yields (capacity fade). Despite having lower voltage efficiencies compared to DAPP2.5, the membrane with an intermediate ion content of 2.0 meq/g (DAPP2.0) exhibited higher coulombic efficiencies (96.4% vs. 89.1%) and electrochem. yields (21.6% vs. 10.9%) after 50 cycles. Crossover of the electroactive species was the primary reason for decreased electrochem. yields. Anal. of the anolyte and catholyte revealed degrdn. of the electroactive species and formation of a film at the membrane-soln. interface. Increases in membrane resistance were attributed to mech. and thermal aging of the membrane; no chem. change was obsd. Improvements in the ionic selectivity and ionic cond. of the membrane will increase the electrochem. yield and voltage efficiency of future nonaq. redox flow batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr%252FP&md5=c3c6c67e1f4669fd89eae4fd7e9fccb0
    130. 130
      Hudak, N. S.; Small, L. J.; Pratt, H. D.; Anderson, T. M. Through-Plane Conductivities of Membranes for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries J. Electrochem. Soc. 2015, 162 (10) A2188– A2194 DOI: 10.1149/2.0901510jes
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      130
      Through-Plane Conductivities of Membranes for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
      Hudak, Nicholas S.; Small, Leo J.; Pratt, Harry D.; Anderson, Travis M.
      Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2015), 162 (10), A2188-A2194CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
      Nonaq. redox flow batteries (RFB) leverage nonaq. solvents to enable higher operating voltages compared to their aq. counterparts. Most com. components for flow batteries, however, are designed for aq. use. One crit. component, the ion-selective membrane, provides ionic conductance between electrodes while preventing crossover of electroactive species. Here we evaluate the area-specific conductances and through-plane conductivities of com. available microporous separators (Celgard 2400, 2500) and anion exchange membranes (Neosepta AFX, Neosepta AHA, Fumasep FAP-450, Fumasep FAP-PK) soaked in acetonitrile, propylene carbonate, or two imidazolium-based ionic liqs. Fumasep membranes combined with acetonitrile-based electrolyte solns. provided the highest conductance values and conductivities by far. When tested in ionic liqs., all anion exchange membranes displayed conductivities greater than those of the Celgard microporous separators, though the separators' decreased thickness-enabled conductances on par with the most conductive anion exchange membranes. Ionic cond. is not the only consideration when choosing an anion exchange membrane; testing of FAP-450 and FAP-PK membranes in a nonaq. RFB demonstrated that the increased mech. stability of PEEK-supported FAP-PK minimized swelling, in turn decreasing solvent mediated crossover and enabling greater electrochem. yields (40% vs. 4%) and Coulombic efficiencies (94% vs. 90%) compared to the unsupported, higher conductance FAP-450.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtlOntb7K&md5=7514f35e84b7df1a623aed9a65275df9
    131. 131
      Luo, Q.; Li, L.; Wang, W.; Nie, Z.; Wei, X.; Li, B.; Chen, B.; Yang, Z. G.; Sprenkle, V. Capacity Decay and Remediation of Nafion-based All-Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries ChemSusChem 2013, 6 (2) 268– 274 DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201200730
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      131
      Capacity Decay and Remediation of Nafion-based All-Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries
      Luo, Qingtao; Li, Liyu; Wang, Wei; Nie, Zimin; Wei, Xiaoliang; Li, Bin; Chen, Baowei; Yang, Zhenguo; Sprenkle, Vincent
      ChemSusChem (2013), 6 (2), 268-274CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The relation between electrochem. performance of V redox flow batteries (VRBs) and electrolyte compn. is studied, and the reasons for capacity decay over charge-discharge cycling are analyzed and discussed herein. The reasons for capacity fading over real charge-discharge cycling include the lack of balance between the V active species and the asym. valence of V ions in pos. and neg. electrolytes. The asym. valence of V ions leads to a state-of-charge (SOC)-range decrease in pos. electrolytes and a SOC-range increase in neg. electrolytes. As a result, the higher SOC range in neg. half-cells further aggravates capacity fading by creating a higher overpotential and possible H evolution. Based on this finding, the authors developed 2 methods for restoring lost capacity, thereby enabling long-term operation of VRBs to be achieved without the substantial loss of energy resulting from periodic total re-mixing of electrolytes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslKntbrN&md5=bbdc9fcccb63015a236ddb1d90592d70

      Janoschka, T.; Martin, N.; Martin, U.; Friebe, C.; Morgenstern, S.; Hiller, H.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. An aqueous, polymer-based redox-flow battery using non-corrosive, safe, and low-cost materials Nature 2015, 527 (7576) 78– 81 DOI: 10.1038/nature15746
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      134
      An aqueous, polymer-based redox-flow battery using non-corrosive, safe, and low-cost materials
      Janoschka, Tobias; Martin, Norbert; Martin, Udo; Friebe, Christian; Morgenstern, Sabine; Hiller, Hannes; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2015), 527 (7576), 78-81CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      For renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydroelec. to be effectively used in the grid of the future, flexible and scalable energy-storage solns. are necessary to mitigate output fluctuations. Redox-flow batteries (RFBs) were 1st built in the 1940s and are considered a promising large-scale energy-storage technol. A limited no. of redox-active materials-mainly metal salts, corrosive halogens, and low-molar-mass org. compds.-have been studied as active materials, and only a few membrane materials, such as Nafion, have been considered for RFBs. However, for systems that are intended for both domestic and large-scale use, safety and cost must be taken into account as well as energy d. and capacity, particularly regarding long-term access to metal resources, which places limits on the Li-ion-based and V-based RFB development. Here the authors describe an affordable, safe, and scalable battery system, which uses org. polymers as the charge-storage material in combination with inexpensive dialysis membranes, which sep. the anode and the cathode by the retention of the nonmetallic, active (macro-mol.) species, and an aq. NaCl soln. as the electrolyte. This H2O- and polymer-based RFB has an energy d. of 10 W hours per L, current densities of up to 100 mA/cm2 and stable long-term cycling capability. The polymer-based RFB the authors present uses an environmentally benign NaCl soln. and cheap, com. available filter membranes instead of highly corrosive acid electrolytes and expensive membrane materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhslynurrN&md5=44665f9a301a89114033ab1fbf7683dd

      Winsberg, J.; Janoschka, T.; Morgenstern, S.; Hagemann, T.; Muench, S.; Hauffman, G.; Gohy, J. F.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. Poly(TEMPO)/Zinc Hybrid-Flow Battery: A Novel, ″Green,″ High Voltage, and Safe Energy Storage System Adv. Mater. 2016, 28 (11) 2238– 2243 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201505000
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      135
      Poly(TEMPO)/Zinc Hybrid-Flow Battery: A Novel, "Green," High Voltage, and Safe Energy Storage System
      Winsberg, Jan; Janoschka, Tobias; Morgenstern, Sabine; Hagemann, Tino; Muench, Simon; Hauffman, Guillaume; Gohy, Jean-Francois; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2016), 28 (11), 2238-2243CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A novel type of zinc hybrid-flow battery was successfully implemented. The application of several TEMPO-contg. polymers, as active cathode material, leads to significant improvements concerning corrosion and environmental impact compared to already known zinc-halogen hybrid-flow batteries. The different applied catholytes comprised P(TEMPO-co-PEGMA)s, synthesized via RAFT polymn. and P(TEMPO-co-METAC), which was designed particularly for aq. solns. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first reported type of flow battery, which enables a stable potential window of up to 2 V in aq. media, without utilization of toxic and expensive heavy metals. Furthermore, a contamination with oxygen is unproblematic rendering the expensive inertization of the battery unnecessary. In carbonate-based electrolytes, high-energy densities of 8.1 Wh/L were achieved, while water based electrolytes allow application of higher current densities of up to 20 mA/cm2 , as well as a stable energy efficiency of over 80%. Furthermore, water-based TEMPO/zinc HFBs feature an elevated OCV of 1.7 V compared to org.-based ones with an OCV of 1.3 V. Both systems showed very good long-term stability of 500 and 1,000 consecutive charging and discharging cycles, resp. When comparing the investigated TEMPO-copolymers with one another, P(TEMPO-co-PEGMA)s are the copolymers of choice for poly(TEMPO)/zinc hybrid-flow batteries. The reported poly(TEMPO)/zinc HFB features high applicable current densities, compared to previously reported TEMPO contg. RFBs, low acquisition costs for both active materials as well as the membrane. The robustness of the employed redox couples leads to high cycle stabilities and, in general, to low intrinsic hazards. This enables the suitability as energy storage system in large scales.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhtl2nu74%253D&md5=ddffd5922a9a7192e6eb62fd80603b95

      Nagarjuna, G.; Hui, J.; Cheng, K. J.; Lichtenstein, T.; Shen, M.; Moore, J. S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, J. Impact of Redox-Active Polymer Molecular Weight on the Electrochemical Properties and Transport Across Porous Separators in Nonaqueous Solvents J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136 (46) 16309– 16316 DOI: 10.1021/ja508482e
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      136
      Impact of Redox-Active Polymer Molecular Weight on the Electrochemical Properties and Transport Across Porous Separators in Nonaqueous Solvents
      Nagarjuna, Gavvalapalli; Hui, Jingshu; Cheng, Kevin J.; Lichtenstein, Timothy; Shen, Mei; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, Joaquin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (46), 16309-16316CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Enhancing the ionic cond. across the electrolyte separator in nonaq. redox flow batteries (NRFBs) is essential for improving their performance and enabling their widespread utilization. Sepg. redox-active species by size exclusion without greatly impeding the transport of supporting electrolyte is a potentially powerful alternative to the use of poorly performing ion-exchange membranes. However, this strategy has not been explored possibly due to the lack of suitable redox-active species that are easily varied in size, remain highly sol., and exhibit good electrochem. properties. Here the synthesis, electrochem. characterization, and transport properties are reported of redox-active poly(vinylbenzyl ethylviologen) (RAPs) with mol. wts. between 21-318 kDa. The RAPs reported here show very good soly. (up to at least 2.0 M) in acetonitrile and propylene carbonate. Ultramicroelectrode voltammetry reveals facile electron transfer with E1/2 ∼ -0.7 V vs. Ag/Ag+(0.1 M) for the viologen 2+/+ redn. at concns. as high as 1.0 M in acetonitrile. Controlled potential bulk electrolysis indicates that 94-99% of the nominal charge on different RAPs is accessible and that the electrolysis products are stable upon cycling. The dependence of the diffusion coeff. on mol. wt. suggests the adequacy of the Stokes-Einstein formalism to describe RAPs. The size-selective transport properties of LiBF4 and RAPs across com. off-the-shelf (COTS) separators such as Celgard 2400 and Celgard 2325 were tested. COTS porous separators show ca. 70 times higher selectivity for charge balancing ions (Li+BF4-) compared to high mol. wt. RAPs. RAPs rejection across these separators showed a strong dependence on polymer mol. wt. as well as the pore size; the rejection increased with both increasing polymer mol. wt. and redn. in pore size. Significant rejection was obsd. even for rpoly/rpore (polymer solvodynamic size relative to pore size) values as low as 0.3. The high concn. attainable (> 2.0 M) for RAPs in common nonaq. battery solvents, their electrochem. and chem. reversibility, and their hindered transport across porous separators make them attractive materials for nonaq. redox flow batteries based on the enabling concept of size-selectivity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslOhu7%252FP&md5=ce24d9e3e5065fa6625d162c6b412e16

      Montoto, E. C.; Nagarjuna, G.; Hui, J.; Burgess, M.; Sekerak, N. M.; Hernandez-Burgos, K.; Wei, T. S.; Kneer, M.; Grolman, J.; Cheng, K. J.; Lewis, J. A.; Moore, J. S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, J. Redox Active Colloids as Discrete Energy Storage Carriers J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138 (40) 13230– 13237 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b06365

      Redox Active Colloids as Discrete Energy Storage Carriers
      Montoto, Elena C.; Nagarjuna, Gavvalapalli; Hui, Jingshu; Burgess, Mark; Sekerak, Nina M.; Hernandez-Burgos, Kenneth; Wei, Teng-Sing; Kneer, Marissa; Grolman, Joshua; Cheng, Kevin J.; Lewis, Jennifer A.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, Joaquin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (40), 13230-13237CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Versatile and readily available battery materials compatible with a range of electrode configurations and cell designs are desirable for renewable energy storage. Here we report a promising class of materials based on redox active colloids (RACs) that are inherently modular in their design and overcome challenges faced by small-mol. org. materials for battery applications, such as crossover and chem./morphol. stability. RACs are cross-linked polymer spheres, synthesized with uniform diams. between 80 and 800 nm, and exhibit reversible redox activity as single particles, as monolayer films, and in the form of flowable dispersions. Viologen-based RACs display reversible cycling, accessing up to 99% of their capacity and 99 ± 1% Coulombic efficiency over 50 cycles by bulk electrolysis owing to efficient, long-distance intraparticle charge transfer. Ferrocene-based RACs paired with viologen-based RACs cycled efficiently in a nonaq. redox flow battery employing a simple size-selective separator, thus demonstrating a possible application that benefits from their colloidal dimensions. The unprecedented versatility in RAC synthetic and electrochem. design opens new avenues for energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsFWnt73L&md5=eb1f512eef10705346a80e0241f4d34d

      Li, C.; Ward, A. L.; Doris, S. E.; Pascal, T. A.; Prendergast, D.; Helms, B. A. Polysulfide-Blocking Microporous Polymer Membrane Tailored for Hybrid Li-Sulfur Flow Batteries Nano Lett. 2015, 15 (9) 5724– 5729 DOI: 10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b02078
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      138
      Polysulfide-Blocking Microporous Polymer Membrane Tailored for Hybrid Li-Sulfur Flow Batteries
      Li, Changyi; Ward, Ashleigh L.; Doris, Sean E.; Pascal, Tod A.; Prendergast, David; Helms, Brett A.
      Nano Letters (2015), 15 (9), 5724-5729CODEN: NALEFD; ISSN:1530-6984. (American Chemical Society)
      Redox flow batteries (RFBs) present unique opportunities for multi-hour electrochem. energy storage (EES) at low cost. Too often, the barrier for implementing them in large-scale EES is the unfettered migration of redox active species across the membrane, which shortens battery life and reduces Coulombic efficiency. To advance RFBs for reliable EES, a new paradigm for controlling membrane transport selectivity is needed. We show here that size- and ion-selective transport can be achieved using membranes fabricated from polymers of intrinsic microporosity (PIMs). As a proof-of-concept demonstration, a first-generation PIM membrane dramatically reduced polysulfide crossover (and shuttling at the anode) in lithium-sulfur batteries, even when sulfur cathodes were prepd. as flowable energy-dense fluids. The design of our membrane platform was informed by mol. dynamics simulations of the solvated structures of lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) vs lithiated polysulfides (Li2Sx, where x = 8, 6, and 4) in glyme-based electrolytes of different oligomer length. These simulations suggested polymer films with pore dimensions less than 1.2-1.7 nm might incur the desired ion-selectivity. Indeed, the polysulfide blocking ability of the PIM-1 membrane (∼0.8 nm pores) was improved 500-fold over mesoporous Celgard separators (∼17 nm pores). As a result, significantly improved battery performance was demonstrated, even in the absence of LiNO3 anode-protecting additives.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1Oqsr3E&md5=1895c9512a6f2c6e5e32445949855bc6

      [Crossref], Google Scholar

      Doris, S. E.; Ward, A. L.; Baskin, A.; Frischmann, P. D.; Gavvalapalli, N.; Chenard, E.; Sevov, C. S.; Prendergast, D.; Moore, J. S.; Helms, B. A. Macromolecular Design Strategies for Preventing Active-Material Crossover in Non-Aqueous All-Organic Redox-Flow Batteries Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2017, 56 (6) 1595– 1599 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201610582
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      140
      Macromolecular Design Strategies for Preventing Active-Material Crossover in Non-Aqueous All-Organic Redox-Flow Batteries
      Doris, Sean E.; Ward, Ashleigh L.; Baskin, Artem; Frischmann, Peter D.; Gavvalapalli, Nagarjuna; Chenard, Etienne; Sevov, Christo S.; Prendergast, David; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Helms, Brett A.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2017), 56 (6), 1595-1599CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Intermittent energy sources, including solar and wind, require scalable, low-cost, multi-hour energy storage solns. in order to be effectively incorporated into the grid. All-Org. non-aq. redox-flow batteries offer a soln., but suffer from rapid capacity fade and low Coulombic efficiency due to the high permeability of redox-active species across the battery's membrane. Here we show that active-species crossover is arrested by scaling the membrane's pore size to mol. dimensions and in turn increasing the size of the active material above the membrane's pore-size exclusion limit. When oligomeric redox-active orgs. (RAOs) were paired with microporous polymer membranes, the rate of active-material crossover was reduced more than 9000-fold compared to traditional separators at minimal cost to ionic cond. This corresponds to an abs. rate of RAO crossover of less than 3 μmol cm-2 day-1 (for a 1.0 M concn. gradient), which exceeds performance targets recently set forth by the battery industry. This strategy was generalizable to both high and low-potential RAOs in a variety of non-aq. electrolytes, highlighting the versatility of macromol. design in implementing next-generation redox-flow batteries.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXlsFCjug%253D%253D&md5=5400264b004f3280d479cf18e4b2a919
    141. 141
      Jia, C.; Pan, F.; Zhu, Y.; Huang, Q.; Lu, L.; Wang, Q. High–energy density nonaqueous all redox flow lithium battery enabled with a polymeric membrane Sci. Adv. 2015, 1 (20) e1500886 DOI: 10.1126/sciadv.1500886
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      141
      High-energy density nonaqueous all redox flow lithium battery enabled with a polymeric membrane
      Jia, Chuankun; Pan, Feng; Zhu, Yun Guang; Huang, Qizhao; Lu, Li; Wang, Qing
      Science Advances (2015), 1 (10), e1500886/1-e1500886/7CODEN: SACDAF; ISSN:2375-2548. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are considered one of the most promising large-scale energy storage technologies. However, conventional RFBs suffer from low energy d. due to the low soly. of the active materials in electrolyte. On the basis of the redox targeting reactions of battery materials, the redox flow lithium battery (RFLB) demonstrated in this report presents a disruptive approach to drastically enhancing the energy d. of flow batteries. With LiFePO4 and TiO2 as the cathodic and anodic Li storage materials, resp., the tank energy d. of RFLB could reach ∼500 W-hours per L (50% porosity), which is 10 times higher than that of a vanadium redox flow battery. The cell exhibits good electrochem. performance under a prolonged cycling test. Our prototype RFLB full cell paves the way toward the development of a new generation of flow batteries for large-scale energy storage.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XovFaktL8%253D&md5=d46ed0521ae6c4b41514cea7fefbbd8d

      Liao, S.; Zong, X.; Seger, B.; Pedersen, T.; Yao, T.; Ding, C.; Shi, J.; Chen, J.; Li, C. Integrating a dual-silicon photoelectrochemical cell into a redox flow battery for unassisted photocharging Nat. Commun. 2016, 7, 11474 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms11474
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      142
      Integrating a dual-silicon photoelectrochemical cell into a redox flow battery for unassisted photocharging
      Liao, Shichao; Zong, Xu; Seger, Brian; Pedersen, Thomas; Yao, Tingting; Ding, Chunmei; Shi, Jingying; Chen, Jian; Li, Can
      Nature Communications (2016), 7 (), 11474CODEN: NCAOBW; ISSN:2041-1723. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Solar rechargeable flow cells (SRFCs) provide an attractive approach for in situ capture and storage of intermittent solar energy via photoelectrochem. regeneration of discharged redox species for electricity generation. However, overall SFRC performance is restricted by inefficient photoelectrochem. reactions. Here we report an efficient SRFC based on a dual-silicon photoelectrochem. cell and a quinone/bromine redox flow battery for in situ solar energy conversion and storage. Using narrow bandgap silicon for efficient photon collection and fast redox couples for rapid interface charge injection, our device shows an optimal solar-to-chem. conversion efficiency of ∼5.9% and an overall photon-chem.-electricity energy conversion efficiency of ∼3.2%, which, to our knowledge, outperforms previously reported SRFCs. The proposed SRFC can be self-photocharged to 0.8 V and delivers a discharge capacity of 730 mAh l-1. Our work may guide future designs for highly efficient solar rechargeable devices.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XnsVels7c%253D&md5=01ce4f3b409a48eff3160b458222c71f

      143
      A redox flow lithium battery based on the redox targeting reactions between LiFePO4 and iodide
      Huang, Qizhao; Yang, Jing; Ng, Chee Boon; Jia, Chuankun; Wang, Qing
      Energy & Environmental Science (2016), 9 (3), 917-921CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      In the search for a reliable and low-cost energy storage system, a lithium-iodide redox flow lithium battery is proposed, which consists of a lithium anode and an iodide catholyte with LiFePO4 as a solid energy storage material. This system demonstrates a good cycling performance and capacity retention. It can potentially achieve an energy d. of 670 W h L-1.

      Reversible chemical delithiation/lithiation of LiFePO4: towards a redox flow lithium-ion battery
      Huang, Qizhao; Li, Hong; Graetzel, Michael; Wang, Qing
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2013), 15 (6), 1793-1797CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Reversible chem. delithiation/lithiation of LiFePO4 was successfully demonstrated using ferrocene derivs., based on which a novel energy storage system - the redox flow lithium-ion battery (RFLB), was devised by integrating the operation flexibility of a redox flow battery and high energy d. of a lithium-ion battery. Distinct from the recent semi-solid lithium rechargeable flow battery, the energy storage materials of RFLB stored in sep. energy tanks remain stationary upon operation, giving one a fresh perspective on building large-scale energy storage systems with higher energy d. and improved safety.

      146
      Redox Targeting of Prussian Blue: Toward Low-Cost and High Energy Density Redox Flow Battery and Solar Rechargeable Battery
      Fan, Li; Jia, Chuankun; Zhu, Yun Guang; Wang, Qing
      ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (3), 615-621CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      The ever-increasing penetration of solar energy demands high energy d., safe and affordable energy storage systems. A redox flow battery is demonstrated on the basis of the redox targeting reactions of a bifunctional redox mediator - Et viologen diiodide (EVI2) with a low-cost pigment material - Prussian blue (PB). Sharing the same I-/I3- based electrolyte, this new battery system can be feasibly integrated with a dye-sensitized TiO2 photoelectrode for photoassisted charging process. The introduction of PB not only increases the energy d. up to 117 Wh/L with good cycling performance and capacity retention, also instantaneously regenerates I- ensuring a stable I-/I3- concn. which is crucial to the operation of the photoelectrode. Wit is anticipated that the work presented here may open an intriguing and credible way for the development of integrated all-in-one solar energy conversion and storage devices for large-scale applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXitFChtrw%253D&md5=559e7567a57ed45600184f76781e00ad

      147
      Unleashing the Power and Energy of LiFePO4-Based Redox Flow Lithium Battery with a Bifunctional Redox Mediator
      Zhu, Yun Guang; Du, Yonghua; Jia, Chuankun; Zhou, Mingyue; Fan, Li; Wang, Xingzhu; Wang, Qing
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (18), 6286-6289CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Redox flow batteries, despite great operation flexibility and scalability for large-scale energy storage, suffer from low energy d. and relatively high cost as compared to the state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries. Here we report a redox flow lithium battery, which operates via the redox targeting reactions of LiFePO4 with a bifunctional redox mediator, 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine, and presents superb energy d. as the Li-ion battery and system flexibility as the redox flow battery. The battery has achieved a tank energy d. as high as 1023 Wh/L, power d. of 61 mW/cm2, and voltage efficiency of 91%. Operando X-ray absorption near-edge structure measurements were conducted to monitor the evolution of LiFePO4, which provides insightful information on the redox targeting process, crit. to the device operation and optimization.

      152
      Aqueous Lithium-Iodine Solar Flow Battery for the Simultaneous Conversion and Storage of Solar Energy
      Yu, Mingzhe; McCulloch, William D.; Beauchamp, Damian R.; Huang, Zhongjie; Ren, Xiaodi; Wu, Yiying
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (26), 8332-8335CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Integrating both photoelec.-conversion and energy-storage functions into one device allows for the more efficient solar energy usage. Here the authors demonstrate the concept of an aq. Li-I (Li-I) solar flow battery (SFB) by incorporation of a built-in dye-sensitized TiO2 photoelectrode in a Li-I redox flow battery via linkage of an I3-/I- based catholyte, for the simultaneous conversion and storage of solar energy. During the photoassisted charging process, I- ions are photoelectrochem. oxidized to I3-, harvesting solar energy and storing it as chem. energy. The Li-I SFB can be charged at a voltage of 2.90 V under 1 sun AM 1.5 illumination, which is lower than its discharging voltage of 3.30 V. The charging voltage redn. translates to energy savings of ∼20% compared to conventional Li-I batteries. This concept also serves as a guiding design that can be extended to other metal-redox flow battery systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A high energy density solar rechargeable redox battery
      Mahmoudzadeh, Mohammad Ali; Usgaocar, Ashwin R.; Giorgio, Joseph; Officer, David L.; Wallace, Gordon G.; Madden, John D. W.
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2016), 4 (9), 3446-3452CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      An integrated solar energy conversion and storage system is presented using a dye sensitized electrode in a redox battery structure. A stable discharge voltage is shown with high areal energy storage capacity of 180 μW h/cm2 by choosing iodide/polysulfide as the pair of active materials matched with permeable porous electrodes. The solar rechargeable battery system offers a higher round-trip efficiency and potential cost savings on fabrication compared to individual devices.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      154
      High Energy Efficiency and Stability for Photoassisted Aqueous Lithium-Iodine Redox Batteries
      Nikiforidis, Georgios; Tajima, Keisuke; Byon, Hye Ryung
      ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (4), 806-813CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors demonstrated photoassisted lithium-iodine (Li-I2) redox cells integrated with a hematite photoelectrode that are applicable to energy storage systems (ESSs). The hematite photoelectrode presents low cost, light absorption in the visible light region, and inertness to aq. electrolytes, which allow for stable prodn. of photocurrent under illumination. In the aq. Li-I2 redox cells, the harnessing of photoenergy generates photocarriers that promote the I- oxidn. process without electrolysis of the aq. soln. The energy efficiency for the photoassisted charge process is ∼95.4%, which is ∼20% higher than that in the absence of illumination at a current rate of 0.075 mA /cm2. The hematite is profoundly stable in aq. I-/I3- catholyte and exhibits over 600 h of cycling without noticeable performance decay and photocorrosion. This achievement highlights photoinduced ESSs with improved energy efficiency.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsFeku7fP&md5=4e5e3cf32d7a7f00dab80860d4b0b84e

      McCulloch, W. D.; Yu, M.; Wu, Y. pH-Tuning a Solar Redox Flow Battery for Integrated Energy Conversion and Storage ACS Energy Lett. 2016, 1 (3) 578– 582 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.6b00296
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      155
      pH-Tuning a Solar Redox Flow Battery for Integrated Energy Conversion and Storage
      McCulloch, William D.; Yu, Mingzhe; Wu, Yiying
      ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (3), 578-582CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
      The intermittent nature of renewable energy sources such as solar and wind requires an energy storage method for future viability. Integrated solar energy conversion and storage devices such as solar redox flow batteries offer an innovative approach to this problem. Herein, we demonstrate electrolyte pH to be a valuable and tunable parameter for optimization of aq. solar redox flow batteries. This can be accomplished by utilizing a pH-dependent redox anolyte and pH-independent catholyte to effectively tune the cell voltage by varying the operating pH, which allows direct integration of a dye-sensitized photoelectrode. A quinone-iodine redox flow battery can achieve high columbic efficiency over ∼90% for 50 cycles under mild pH conditions (pH ∼ 2-8). Furthermore, a pH-tunable solar redox flow battery can be charged using only solar illumination, thus allowing for integrated energy conversion and storage within a single device.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtlOqtb%252FL&md5=aadb0c01b0dd91d8048746d6016eaff6

      Integrated Photoelectrochemical Solar Energy Conversion and Organic Redox Flow Battery Devices
      Li, Wenjie; Fu, Hui-Chun; Li, Linsen; Caban-Acevedo, Miguel; He, Jr-Hau; Jin, Song
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (42), 13104-13108CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Building on regenerative photoelectrochem. solar cells and emerging electrochem. redox flow batteries (RFBs), more efficient, scalable, compact, and cost-effective hybrid energy conversion and storage devices could be realized. An integrated photoelectrochem. solar energy conversion and electrochem. storage device is developed by integrating regenerative silicon solar cells and 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS)/1,2-benzoquinone-3,5-disulfonic acid (BQDS) RFBs. The device can be directly charged by solar light without external bias, and discharged like normal RFBs with an energy storage d. of 1.15 Wh L-1 and a solar-to-output electricity efficiency (SOEE) of 1.7 % over many cycles. The concept exploits a previously undeveloped design connecting two major energy technologies and promises a general approach for storing solar energy electrochem. with high theor. storage capacity and efficiency.

      Jain, A.; Shin, Y.; Persson, K. A. Computational predictions of energy materials using density functional theory Nat. Rev. Mater. 2016, 1, 15004 DOI: 10.1038/natrevmats.2015.4

      157
      Computational predictions of energy materials using density functional theory
      Jain, Anubhav; Shin, Yongwoo; Persson, Kristin A.
      Nature Reviews Materials (2016), 1 (1), 15004CODEN: NRMADL; ISSN:2058-8437. (Nature Publishing Group)
      In the search for new functional materials, quantum mechanics is an exciting starting point. The fundamental laws that govern the behavior of electrons have the possibility, at the other end of the scale, to predict the performance of a material for a targeted application. In some cases, this is achievable using d. functional theory (DFT). In this Review, we highlight DFT studies predicting energy-related materials that were subsequently confirmed exptl. The attributes and limitations of DFT for the computational design of materials for lithium-ion batteries, hydrogen prodn. and storage materials, superconductors, photovoltaics and thermoelec. materials are discussed. In the future, we expect that the accuracy of DFT-based methods will continue to improve and that growth in computing power will enable millions of materials to be virtually screened for specific applications. Thus, these examples represent a first glimpse of what may become a routine and integral step in materials discovery.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVertr4%253D&md5=1049e10124b0dd3c4f3c74b914a942d7

      Kanal, I. Y.; Owens, S. G.; Bechtel, J. S.; Hutchison, G. R. Efficient Computational Screening of Organic Polymer Photovoltaics J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2013, 4 (10) 1613– 1623 DOI: 10.1021/jz400215j
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      158
      Efficient computational screening of organic polymer photovoltaics
      Kanal, Ilana Y.; Owens, Steven G.; Bechtel, Jonathon S.; Hutchison, Geoffrey R.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters (2013), 4 (10), 1613-1623CODEN: JPCLCD; ISSN:1948-7185. (American Chemical Society)
      Review. There has been increasing interest in rational, computationally driven design methods for materials, including org. photovoltaics (OPVs). Our approach focuses on a screening "pipeline", using a genetic algorithm for first stage screening and multiple filtering stages for further refinement. An important step forward is to expand our diversity of candidate compds., including both synthetic and property-based measures of diversity. For example, top monomer pairs from our screening are all donor-donor (D-D) combinations, in contrast with the typical donor-acceptor (D-A) motif used in org. photovoltaics. We also find a strong "sequence effect", in which the av. HOMO-LUMO gap of tetramers changes by ∼0.2 eV as a function of monomer sequence (e.g., ABBA vs. BAAB); this has rarely been explored in conjugated polymers. Beyond such optoelectronic optimization, we discuss other properties needed for high-efficiency org. solar cells, and applications of screening methods to other areas, including non-fullerene n-type materials, tandem cells, and improving charge and exciton transport.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmsFGktro%253D&md5=85b4807c36484c8ad37cd8d9cd6d8eb8

      Er, S.; Suh, C.; Marshak, M. P.; Aspuru-Guzik, A. Computational design of molecules for an all-quinone redox flow battery Chem. Sci. 2015, 6 (2) 885– 893 DOI: 10.1039/C4SC03030C
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Computational design of molecules for an all-quinone redox flow battery
      Er, Suleyman; Suh, Changwon; Marshak, Michael P.; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan
      Chemical Science (2015), 6 (2), 885-893CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Inspired by the electron transfer properties of quinones in biol. systems, we recently showed that quinones are also very promising electroactive materials for stationary energy storage applications. Due to the practically infinite chem. space of org. mols., the discovery of addnl. quinones or other redox-active org. mols. for energy storage applications is an open field of inquiry. Here, we introduce a high-throughput computational screening approach that we applied to an accelerated study of a total of 1710 quinone (Q) and hydroquinone (QH2) (i.e., two-electron two-proton) redox couples. We identified the promising candidates for both the neg. and pos. sides of org.-based aq. flow batteries, thus enabling an all-quinone battery. To further aid the development of addnl. interesting electroactive small mols. we also provide emerging quant. structure-property relationships.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Cheng, L.; Assary, R. S.; Qu, X.; Jain, A.; Ong, S. P.; Rajput, N. N.; Persson, K.; Curtiss, L. A. Accelerating Electrolyte Discovery for Energy Storage with High-Throughput Screening J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2015, 6 (2) 283– 291 DOI: 10.1021/jz502319n
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      162
      Accelerating Electrolyte Discovery for Energy Storage with High-Throughput Screening
      Cheng, Lei; Assary, Rajeev S.; Qu, Xiaohui; Jain, Anubhav; Ong, Shyue Ping; Rajput, Nav Nidhi; Persson, Kristin; Curtiss, Larry A.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters (2015), 6 (2), 283-291CODEN: JPCLCD; ISSN:1948-7185. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Computational screening techniques are an effective alternative to the trial and error of experimentation for discovery of new materials. With increased interest in development of advanced elec. energy storage systems, it is essential to find new electrolytes that function effectively. This Perspective reviews various methods for screening electrolytes and then describes a hierarchical computational scheme to screen multiple properties of advanced elec. energy storage electrolytes using high-throughput quantum chem. calcns. The approach effectively down-selects a large pool of candidates based on successive property evaluation. As an example, results of screening are presented for redox potentials, solvation energies, and structural changes of ∼1400 org. mols. for nonaq. redox flow batteries. Importantly, from high-throughput screening, in silico design of suitable candidate mols. for synthesis and electrochem. testing can be achieved. The authors anticipate that the computational approach described in this Perspective coupled with experimentation will have a significant role to play in the discovery of materials for future energy needs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXitFGrsr3M&md5=d70433954ee4c606c3bc665c2cbd7718
    163. 163
      Qu, X.; Jain, A.; Rajput, N. N.; Cheng, L.; Zhang, Y.; Ong, S. P.; Brafman, M.; Maginn, E.; Curtiss, L. A.; Persson, K. A. The Electrolyte Genome project: A big data approach in battery materials discovery Comput. Mater. Sci. 2015, 103, 56– 67 DOI: 10.1016/j.commatsci.2015.02.050
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      163
      The Electrolyte Genome project: A big data approach in battery materials discovery
      Qu, Xiaohui; Jain, Anubhav; Rajput, Nav Nidhi; Cheng, Lei; Zhang, Yong; Ong, Shyue Ping; Brafman, Miriam; Maginn, Edward; Curtiss, Larry A.; Persson, Kristin A.
      Computational Materials Science (2015), 103 (), 56-67CODEN: CMMSEM; ISSN:0927-0256. (Elsevier B.V.)
      We present a high-throughput infrastructure for the automated calcn. of mol. properties with a focus on battery electrolytes. The infrastructure is largely open-source and handles both practical aspects (input file generation, output file parsing, and information management) as well as more complex problems (structure matching, salt complex generation, and failure recovery). Using this infrastructure, we have computed the ionization potential (IP) and electron affinities (EA) of 4830 mols. relevant to battery electrolytes (encompassing almost 55,000 quantum mechanics calcns.) at the B3LYP/6-31+G* level. We describe automated workflows for computing redox potential, dissocn. const., and salt-mol. binding complex structure generation. We present routines for automatic recovery from calcn. errors, which brings the failure rate from 9.2% to 0.8% for the QChem DFT code. Automated algorithms to check duplication between two arbitrary mols. and structures are described. We present benchmark data on basis sets and functionals on the G2-97 test set; one finding is that a IP/EA calcn. method that combines PBE geometry optimization and B3LYP energy evaluation requires less computational cost and yields nearly identical results as compared to a full B3LYP calcn., and could be suitable for the calcn. of large mols. Our data indicates that among the 8 functionals tested, XYGJ-OS and B3LYP are the two best functionals to predict IP/EA with an RMSE of 0.12 and 0.27 eV, resp. Application of our automated workflow to a large set of quinoxaline deriv. mols. shows that functional group effect and substitution position effect can be sepd. for IP/EA of quinoxaline derivs., and the most sensitive position is different for IP and EA.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXksFSrurk%253D&md5=b7202aed2369b45f537b39e75f7a0e7d
    164. 164
      Obtained as the lowest prices from Alibaba.com (Accessed August 18, 2018) .
      Google Scholar
