        Cosimbescu, L.; Wei, X.; Vijayakumar, M.; Xu, W.; Helm, M. L.; Burton, S. D.; Sorensen, C. M.; Liu, J.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. Anion-Tunable Properties and Electrochemical Performance of Functionalized Ferrocene Compounds Sci. Rep. 2015, 14117 DOI: 10.1038/srep14117
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        76
        Anion-Tunable Properties and Electrochemical Performance of Functionalized Ferrocene Compounds
        Cosimbescu, Lelia; Wei, Xiaoliang; Vijayakumar, M.; Xu, Wu; Helm, Monte L.; Burton, Sarah D.; Sorensen, Christina M.; Liu, Jun; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
        Scientific Reports (2015), 5 (), 14117CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
        We report a series of ionically modified ferrocene compds. for hybrid lithium-org. non-aq. redox flow batteries, based on the ferrocene/ferrocenium redox couple as the active catholyte material. Tetraalkylammonium ionic moieties were incorporated into the ferrocene structure, in order to enhance the soly. of the otherwise relatively insol. ferrocene. The effect of various counter anions of the tetraalkylammonium ionized species appended to the ferrocene, such as bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide, hexafluorophosphate, perchlorate, tetrafluoroborate, and dicyanamide on the soly. of the ferrocene was investigated. The soln. chem. of the ferrocene species was studied, in order to understand the mechanism of soly. enhancement. Finally, the electrochem. performance of these ionized ferrocene species was evaluated and shown to have excellent cell efficiency and superior cycling stability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFeis7nE&md5=4cc6fa05aa0f4dc0a6fd9d773b0973c6

      78. 78
        Cong, G.; Zhou, Y.; Li, Z.; Lu, Y. A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Enabled by a Low-Melting-Point Ferrocene Derivative ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (4) 869– 875 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b00115
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        78
        A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Enabled by a Low-Melting-Point Ferrocene Derivative
        Cong, Guangtao; Zhou, Yucun; Li, Zhejun; Lu, Yi-Chun
        ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (4), 869-875CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Nonaq. redox flow batteries (NRFBs) exhibit a wide potential window (>3.0 V) but have been limited by the low soly. of the active materials. Here, the authors propose and demonstrate a high-energy-d. nonaq. redox flow battery based on a low-melting-point (37-40°) ferrocene deriv., 1,1'-dimethyl-ferrocene (DMFc), operated at its liq. state. The liq. redox-active DMFc not only contributes to high capacity but also acts as a solvating medium to the ion-conducting salts. Taking advantage of DMFc's high concn. (3 M), superior stability, and fast kinetics, the Li/DMFc battery achieves a high volumetric d. (∼68 A h L-1catholyte) with a high Coulombic efficiency (>95%) and high cycling stability. Exploiting a low-melting-point redox-active species at its melting state is a promising direction for developing high-energy-d. NRFBs for next-generation energy storage technologies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXktlymsrs%253D&md5=9f245e5b91f28d45f901a08cab466650
      79. 79
        Beh, E. S.; De Porcellinis, D.; Gracia, R. L.; Xia, K.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. A Neutral pH Aqueous Organic-Organometallic Redox Flow Battery with Extremely High Capacity Retention ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (3) 639– 644 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b00019
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        A Neutral pH Aqueous Organic-Organometallic Redox Flow Battery with Extremely High Capacity Retention
        Beh, Eugene S.; De Porcellinis, Diana; Gracia, Rebecca L.; Xia, Kay T.; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (3), 639-644CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        We demonstrate an aq. org. and organometallic redox flow battery utilizing reactants composed of only earth-abundant elements and operating at neutral pH. The pos. electrolyte contains bis((3-trimethylammonio)propyl)ferrocene dichloride, and the neg. electrolyte contains bis(3-trimethylammonio)propyl viologen tetrachloride; these are sepd. by an anion-conducting membrane passing chloride ions. Bis(trimethylammoniopropyl) functionalization leads to ∼2 M soly. for both reactants, suppresses higher-order chem. decompn. pathways, and reduces reactant crossover rates through the membrane. Unprecedented cycling stability was achieved with capacity retention of 99.9943%/cycle and 99.90%/day at a 1.3 M reactant concn., increasing to 99.9989%/cycle and 99.967%/day at 0.75-1.00 M; these represent the highest capacity retention rates reported to date vs. time and vs. cycle no. We discuss opportunities for future performance improvement, including chem. modification of a ferrocene center and reducing the membrane resistance without unacceptable increases in reactant crossover. This approach may provide the decadal lifetimes that enable org.-organometallic redox flow batteries to be cost-effective for grid-scale electricity storage, thereby enabling massive penetration of intermittent renewable electricity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXit12msrY%253D&md5=0b27106e1380cef821781323bd6cbeb7
      80. 80
        Han, K.; Rajput, N. N.; Vijayakumar, M.; Wei, X.; Wang, W.; Hu, J.; Persson, K. A.; Mueller, K. T. Preferential Solvation of an Asymmetric Redox Molecule J. Phys. Chem. C 2016, 120 (49) 27834– 27839 DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b09114
        [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar

      81. 81
        Deng, X.; Hu, M.; Wei, X.; Wang, W.; Mueller, K. T.; Chen, Z.; Hu, J. Nuclear magnetic resonance studies of the solvation structures of a high-performance nonaqueous redox flow electrolyte J. Power Sources 2016, 308, 172– 179 DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.12.005
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        81
        Nuclear magnetic resonance studies of the solvation structures of a high-performance nonaqueous redox flow electrolyte
        Deng, Xuchu; Hu, Mary; Wei, Xiaoliang; Wang, Wei; Mueller, Karl T.; Chen, Zhong; Hu, Jian Zhi
        Journal of Power Sources (2016), 308 (), 172-179CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Understanding the solvation structures of electrolytes is important for developing nonaq. redox flow batteries that hold considerable potential for future large scale energy storage systems. The utilization of an emerging ionic-derivatived ferrocene compd., ferrocenylmethyl di-Me Et ammonium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (Fc1N112-TFSI), has recently overcome the issue of soly. in the supporting electrolyte. In this work, 13C, 1H and 17O NMR investigations were carried out using electrolyte solns. consisting of Fc1N112-TFSI as the solute and the mixed alkyl carbonate as the solvent. It was obsd. that the spectra of 13C experience changes of chem. shifts while those of 17O undergo linewidth broadening, indicating interactions between solute and solvent mols. Quantum chem. calcns. of both mol. structures and chem. shifts (13C, 1H and 17O) are performed for interpreting exptl. results and for understanding the detailed solvation structures. The results indicate that Fc1N112-TFSI is dissocd. at varying degrees in mixed solvent depending on concns. At dil. solute concns., most Fc1N112+ and TFSI- are fully disassocd. with their own solvation shells formed by solvent mols. At satd. concn., Fc1N112+-TFSI- contact ion pairs are formed and the solvent mols. are preferentially interacting with the Fc rings rather than interacting with the ionic pendant arm of Fc1N112-TFSI.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitlSmtL8%253D&md5=128831497037e0deff8e49cee483a85c
      82. 82
        Han, K.; Rajput, N. N.; Wei, X.; Wang, W.; Hu, J.; Persson, K. A.; Mueller, K. T. Diffusional motion of redox centers in carbonate electrolytes J. Chem. Phys. 2014, 141 (10) 104509 DOI: 10.1063/1.4894481
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        82
        Diffusional motion of redox centers in carbonate electrolytes
        Han, Kee Sung; Rajput, Nav Nidhi; Wei, Xiaoliang; Wang, Wei; Hu, Jian Zhi; Persson, Kristin A.; Mueller, Karl T.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (2014), 141 (10), 104509/1-104509/8CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
        Ferrocene (Fc) and N-(ferrocenylmethyl)-N,N-dimethyl-N-ethylammonium bistrifluoromethyl-sulfonimide (Fc1N112-TFSI) were dissolved in carbonate solvents and self-diffusion coeffs. (D) of solutes and solvents were measured by 1H and 19F pulsed field gradient NMR (NMR) spectroscopy. The org. solvents were propylene carbonate (PC), Et Me carbonate (EMC), and a ternary mixt. that also includes ethylene carbonate (EC). Results from NMR studies over the temp. range of 0-50 °C and for various concns. (0.25-1.7 M) of Fc1N112-TFSI are compared to values of D simulated with classical mol. dynamics (MD). The measured self-diffusion coeffs. gradually decreased as the Fc1N112-TFSI concn. increased in all solvents. Since TFSI- has fluoromethyl groups (CF3), DTFSI could be measured sep. and the values found are larger than those for DFc1N112 in all samples measured. The EC, PC, and EMC have the same D in the neat solvent mixt. and when Fc is dissolved in EC/PC/EMC at a concn. of 0.2 M, probably due to the interactions between common carbonyl structures within EC, PC, and EMC. A difference in D (DPC < DEC < DEMC), and both a higher Ea for translational motion and higher effective viscosity for PC in the mixt. contg. Fc1N112-TFSI reflect the interaction between PC and Fc1N112+, which is a relatively stronger interaction than that between Fc1N112+ and other solvent species. In the EC/PC/EMC soln. that is satd. with Fc1N112-TFSI, we find that DPC = DEC = DEMC and Fc1N112+ and all components of the EC/PC/EMC soln. have the same Ea for translational motion, while the ratio DEC/PC/EMC/DFc1N112 is approx. 3. These results reflect the lack of available free vol. for independent diffusion in the satd. soln. The Fc1N112+ transference nos. lie around 0.4 and increase slightly as the temp. is increased in the PC and EMC solvents. The trends obsd. for D from simulations are in good agreement with exptl. results and provide mol. level understanding of the solvation structure of Fc1N112-TFSI dissolved in EC/PC/EMC. (c) 2014 American Institute of Physics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFeks7fJ&md5=0a06f83e145ef303570510d2595ba5b7
      83. 83
        Ding, Y.; Zhao, Y.; Li, Y.; Goodenough, J. B.; Yu, G. A high-performance all-metallocene-based, non-aqueous redox flow battery Energy Environ. Sci. 2017, 10, 491– 497 DOI: 10.1039/C6EE02057G
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        83
        A high-performance all-metallocene-based, non-aqueous redox flow battery
        Ding, Yu; Zhao, Yu; Li, Yutao; Goodenough, John B.; Yu, Guihua
        Energy & Environmental Science (2017), 10 (2), 491-497CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Here, a class of organometallic compds., metallocenes, are explored to serve as both catholyte and anolyte redox species for non-aq. lithium-based redox flow battery (Li-RFB) applications. The prototype of all-metallocene-based Li-RFB exploits ferrocene (FeCp2) and cobaltocene (CoCp2) as the redox-active cathode and anode, resp. The reaction rate consts. of metallocenes are detd. to be as high as 10-3 cm s-1, two orders greater than most redox-active materials applied in conventional redox flow batteries. This designed Li-RFB yields a working potential of 1.7 V, and by introduction of Me groups on the ligand rings of CoCp2, the working potential can be further increased to 2.1 V. The fabricated full cell shows capacity retention of over 99% per cycle with a coulombic efficiency (CE) of >95% and an energy efficiency of >85%. These results demonstrate a generic design route towards high performance non-aq. RFBs via rational screening and functionalization of metallocenes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1CgtbrL&md5=1a35b30f1042089f9c04fbc8860a7ac8

        Brushett, F. R.; Vaughey, J. T.; Jansen, A. N. An All-Organic Non-aqueous Lithium-Ion Redox Flow Battery Adv. Energy Mater. 2012, 2 (11) 1390– 1396 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201200322
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        85
        An all-organic non-aqueous lithium-ion redox flow battery
        Brushett, Fikile R.; Vaughey, John T.; Jansen, Andrew N.
        Advanced Energy Materials (2012), 2 (11), 1390-1396CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        A non-aq. lithium-ion redox flow battery employing org. mols. is proposed and investigated. 2,5-Di-tert-butyl-1,4-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)benzene and a variety of mols. derived from quinoxaline are employed as initial high-potential and low-potential active materials, resp. Electrochem. measurements highlight that the choice of electrolyte and of substituent groups can have a significant impact on redox species performance. The charge-discharge characteristics are investigated in a modified coin-cell configuration. After an initial break-in period, coulombic and energy efficiencies for this unoptimized system are ∼70% and ∼37%, resp., with major charge and discharge plateaus between 1.8-2.4 V and 1.7-1.3 V, resp., for 30 cycles. Performance enhancements are expected with improvements in cell design and materials processing.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhsleru73E&md5=265e83f8a61564f28e61e7e352666cf8
      86. 86
        Zhang, L.; Zhang, Z.; Redfern, P. C.; Curtiss, L. A.; Amine, K. Molecular engineering towards safer lithium-ion batteries: a highly stable and compatible redox shuttle for overcharge protection Energy Environ. Sci. 2012, 5 (8) 8204– 8207 DOI: 10.1039/c2ee21977h
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        86
        Molecular engineering towards safer lithium-ion batteries: a highly stable and compatible redox shuttle for overcharge protection
        Zhang, Lu; Zhang, Zhengcheng; Redfern, Paul C.; Curtiss, Larry A.; Amine, Khalil
        Energy & Environmental Science (2012), 5 (8), 8204-8207CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Overcharge abuse is one of the most common and dangerous safety issues with state-of-the-art lithium-ion batteries. Thus, incorporation of overcharge prevention into the lithium-ion battery pack is key to its practical application. Redox shuttle mols. that can be reversibly oxidized and reduced at specific potentials (redox potential) provide an effective and economic method to prevent overcharge abuse for lithium-ion batteries. We have developed a novel oligo(ethylene glycol)-functionalized redox shuttle, 2,5-di-tert-butyl-1,4-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)benzene (DBBB), that is not only capable of providing efficient and long-lasting overcharge protection to lithium-ion batteries (capable of withstanding over 180 cycles of 100% overcharge at the C/2 rate), but is also compatible with the state-of-the-art lithium-ion cell system. D. functional theory calcns. provided an understanding of the stability properties of this new redox shuttle.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVylu7fK&md5=53c31aa65bd3f725e132770770e8b88a

        This article describes the liq. catholyte mols. for nonaq. redox flow batteries. In this article a new series of redox active mols. has been designed and synthesized as new catholyte mols. to improve the soly. was discussed.

        Wei, X.; Xu, W.; Huang, J.; Zhang, L.; Walter, E.; Lawrence, C.; Vijayakumar, M.; Henderson, W. A.; Liu, T.; Cosimbescu, L.; Li, B.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W.         88
        Radical Compatibility with Nonaqueous Electrolytes and Its Impact on an All-Organic Redox Flow Battery
        Wei, Xiaoliang; Xu, Wu; Huang, Jinhua; Zhang, Lu; Walter, Eric; Lawrence, Chad; Vijayakumar, M.; Henderson, Wesley A.; Liu, Tianbiao; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Li, Bin; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (30), 8684-8687CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Nonaq. redox flow batteries hold the promise of achieving higher energy d. because of the broader voltage window than aq. systems, but their current performance is limited by low redox material concn., cell efficiency, cycling stability, and c.d. The authors report a new nonaq. all-org. flow battery based on high concns. of redox materials, which shows significant, comprehensive improvement in flow battery performance. A mechanistic ESR study reveals that the choice of supporting electrolytes greatly affects the chem. stability of the charged radical species esp. the neg. side radical anion, which dominates the cycling stability of these flow cells. This finding not only increases the fundamental understanding of performance degrdn. in flow batteries using radical-based redox species, but also offers insights toward rational electrolyte optimization for improving the cycling stability of these flow batteries.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        89
        A High-Current, Stable Nonaqueous Organic Redox Flow Battery
        Wei, Xiaoliang; Duan, Wentao; Huang, Jinhua; Zhang, Lu; Li, Bin; Reed, David; Xu, Wu; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
        ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (4), 705-711CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Nonaq. redox flow batteries are promising in pursuit of high energy d. storage systems owing to the broad voltage windows ( > 2 V) but currently are facing key challenges such as limited cyclability and rate performance. To address these tech. hurdles, here the authors report the nonaq. org. flow battery chem. based on N-methylphthalimide anolyte and 2,5-di-tert-butyl-1-methoxy-4-[2'-methoxyethoxy]benzene catholyte, which harvests a theor. cell voltage of 2.30 V. The redox flow chem. exhibits excellent cycling stability under both cyclic voltammetry and flow cell tests upon repeated cycling. Daramic and Celgard porous separators are evaluated in this org. flow battery, which enable the cells to be operated at greatly improved current densities ≤50 mA/cm2 compared to those of other nonaq. flow systems. The stable cyclability and high-current operations of the org. flow battery system represent significant progress in the development of promising nonaq. flow batteries.

        91
        A subtractive approach to molecular engineering of dimethoxybenzene-based redox materials for non-aqueous flow batteries
        Huang, Jinhua; Su, Liang; Kowalski, Jeffrey A.; Barton, John L.; Ferrandon, Magali; Burrell, Anthony K.; Brushett, Fikile R.; Zhang, Lu
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2015), 3 (29), 14971-14976CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The development of new high capacity redox active materials is key to realizing the potential of non-aq. redox flow batteries (RFBs). In this paper, a series of substituted 1,4-dimethoxybenzene based redox active mols. have been developed via a subtractive design approach. Five mols. have been proposed and developed by removing or reducing the bulky substituent groups of DBBB (2,5-di-tert-butyl-1,4-bis(2-methoxyethoxy)benzene), a successful overcharge protection material for lithium-ion batteries. Of these derivs., 2,3-dimethyl-1,4-dimethoxybenzene (23DDB) and 2,5-dimethyl-1,4-dimethoxybenzene (25DDB) are particularly promising as they demonstrate favorable electrochem. characteristics at gravimetric capacities (161 mA h g-1) that approach the stability limit of chem. reversible dimethoxybenzene based structures. Diffusivity, soly., and galvanostatic cycling results indicate that both 23DDB and 25DDB mols. have promise for non-aq. RFBs.

        Huang, J.; Pan, B.; Duan, W.; Wei, X.; Assary, R. S.; Su, L.; Brushett, F. R.; Cheng, L.; Liao, C.; Ferrandon, M. S.; Wang, W.; Zhang, Z.; Burrell, A. K.; Curtiss, L. A.; Shkrob, I.         92
        The lightest organic radical cation for charge storage in redox flow batteries
        Huang, Jinhua; Pan, Baofei; Duan, Wentao; Wei, Xiaoliang; Assary, Rajeev S.; Su, Liang; Brushett, Fikile R.; Cheng, Lei; Liao, Chen; Ferrandon, Magali S.; Wang, Wei; Zhang, Zhengcheng; Burrell, Anthony K.; Curtiss, Larry A.; Shkrob, Ilya A.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Zhang, Lu
        Scientific Reports (2016), 6 (), 32102CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
        In advanced elec. grids of the future, electrochem. rechargeable fluids of high energy d. will capture the power generated from intermittent sources like solar and wind. To meet this outstanding technol. demand there is a need to understand the fundamental limits and interplay of electrochem. potential, stability, and soly. in low-wt. redox-active mols. By generating a combinatorial set of 1,4-dimethoxybenzene derivs. with different arrangements of substituents, we discovered a minimalistic structure that combines exceptional long-term stability in its oxidized form and a record-breaking intrinsic capacity of 161 mAh/g. The nonaq. redox flow battery has been demonstrated that uses this mol. as a catholyte material and operated stably for 100 charge/discharge cycles. The obsd. stability trends are rationalized by mechanistic considerations of the reaction pathways.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Yang, B.; Murali, A.; Nirmalchandar, A.; Prakash, G. K. S.; Narayanan, S. R. A New Michael-Reaction-Resistant Benzoquinone for Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries J. Electrochem. Soc. 2017, 164 (4) A600– A607 DOI: 10.1149/2.0351704jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        93
        A New Michael-Reaction-Resistant Benzoquinone for Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries
        Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Krishnamoorthy, Sankarganesh; Yang, Bo; Murali, Advaith; Nirmalchandar, Archith; Prakash, G. K. Surya; Narayanan, S. R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2017), 164 (4), A600-A607CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The synthesis, characterization and properties are reported of 3,6-dihydroxy-2,4-dimethylbenzenesulfonic acid (DHDMBS) as a new pos. side electrolyte material for aq. org. redox flow batteries (ORBAT). This material is synthesized in pure form in high yield and its structure is confirmed. It was detd. that the std. redn. potential, the rate const. of the redox reaction, and the diffusion coeff. are ideally suited for use in ORBAT. Specifically, DHDMBS overcomes the major issue of Michael reaction with water faced with 4,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,3-disulfonic acid (BQDS) and similar unsubstituted benzoquinones in the selection of pos. electrolyte materials. The DHDMBS can be synthesized relatively inexpensively. The chem. stability is demonstrated of DHDMBS to repeated electrochem. cycling through NMR and electrochem. studies proving the absence of products of the Michael reaction. A flow cell with DHDMBS and anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid has now been shown to operate close to 100% coulombic efficiency for over 25 cycles when continuously cycled at 100 mA/cm2, and can sustain current densities as high as 500 mA/cm2 without noticeable chem. degrdn. However, there was a slow decrease in the capacity of the flow cell attributable to the crossover of DHDMBS from the pos. side of the cell. Thus, the present study has shown DHDMBS as a promising candidate for the pos. side material for an all-org. aq. redox flow battery in acidic media, and the future efforts will focus on understanding the crossover of DHDMBS and the effects of long-term cycling.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXktlGqsL8%253D&md5=28a87d3dfcaeacc9a68da412239067fa

        A nonaq., hybrid metal-org. redox flow battery based on a tailored anthraquinone structure has an energy efficiency of ∼82% and a sp. discharge energy d. similar to those of aq. redox flow batteries, which is due to the improved soly. of anthraquinone in supporting electrolytes.

        Carney, T. J.; Collins, S. J.; Moore, J. S.; Brushett, F. R. Concentration-Dependent Dimerization of Anthraquinone Disulfonic Acid and Its Impact on Charge Storage Chem. Mater. 2017, 29 (11) 4801– 4810 DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.7b00616

        95
        Concentration-Dependent Dimerization of Anthraquinone Disulfonic Acid and Its Impact on Charge Storage
        Carney, Thomas J.; Collins, Steven J.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Brushett, Fikile R.
        Chemistry of Materials (2017), 29 (11), 4801-4810CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        9,10-Anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) is considered a benchmark active material for aq. org. redox flow batteries. At low concn., AQDS demonstrates 2-electron transfer at near ideal electrochem. reversibility; however, at higher concn., AQDS displays more complex behavior presumably due to the emergence of intermol. reactions. Here, the authors systematically examine the electrochem. and phys. properties of AQDS solns. using a suite of electrochem., anal., and spectroscopic techniques. Depending on the AQDS pretreatment, concn., soln. pH, and electrolyte compn., coupled chem. and electrochem. reactions lead to different charge storage capabilities. To elucidate the underlying cause of these differences, the authors performed various pre-treatments of AQDS, examd. chem. speciation by NMR, and studied the corresponding electrochem. properties through cyclic voltammetry and bulk electrolysis. In all cases, reversible intermol. dimerization was detected at soln. concns. >10 mM. Also, the charge state of the formed dimers was dependent on the AQDS pretreatment and the soln. pH. Under acidic conditions, 1.5 electrons per mol. of AQDS were reversibly accessible, whereas under buffered mild-alk. conditions, only one electron per mol. of AQDS was accessible. Because of insufficient p concn., AQDS did not cycle reversibly in unbuffered neutral electrolyte. Even when employing chem. oxidants during a chem. titrn., charge storage of 2 electrons per mol. could not be realized. The authors hypothesize that adduct formation between AQDS and CO2, along with soln. pH, play important roles in the charge accessibility.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXotVGmsLw%253D&md5=9136a3dc58d7b524bd9ca74e62935a3e

        Lin, K.; Chen, Q.; Gerhardt, M. R.; Tong, L.; Kim, S. B.; Eisenach, L.; Valle, A. W.; Hardee, D.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J.; Marshak, M. P. Alkaline quinone flow battery Science 2015, 349 (6255) 1529– 1532 DOI: 10.1126/science.aab3033
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        98
        Alkaline quinone flow battery
        Lin, Kaixiang; Chen, Qing; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Tong, Liuchuan; Kim, Sang Bok; Eisenach, Louise; Valle, Alvaro W.; Hardee, David; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.; Marshak, Michael P.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2015), 349 (6255), 1529-1532CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Storage of photovoltaic and wind electricity in batteries could solve the mismatch problem between the intermittent supply of these renewable resources and variable demand. Flow batteries permit more economical long-duration discharge than solid-electrode batteries by using liq. electrolytes stored outside of the battery. We report an alk. flow battery based on redox-active org. mols. that are composed entirely of Earth-abundant elements and are nontoxic, nonflammable, and safe for use in residential and com. environments. The battery operates efficiently with high power d. near room temp. These results demonstrate the stability and performance of redox-active org. mols. in alk. flow batteries, potentially enabling cost-effective stationary storage of renewable energy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFCrtbjN&md5=03e98c7de27aa2f1cfe9c71b6e9823bc
      99. 99
        Yang, B.; Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Wang, F.; Surya Prakash, G. K.; Narayanan, S. R. An Inexpensive Aqueous Flow Battery for Large-Scale Electrical Energy Storage Based on Water-Soluble Organic Redox Couples J. Electrochem. Soc. 2014, 161 (9) A1371– A1380 DOI: 10.1149/2.1001409jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        99
        An Inexpensive Aqueous Flow Battery for Large-Scale Electrical Energy Storage Based on Water-Soluble Organic Redox Couples
        Yang, Bo; Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Wang, Fang; Surya Prakash, G. K.; Narayanan, S. R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2014), 161 (9), A1371-A1380CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        We introduce a novel Org. Redox Flow Battery (ORBAT), for meeting the demanding requirements of cost, eco-friendliness, and durability for large-scale energy storage. ORBAT employs two different water-sol. org. redox couples on the pos. and neg. side of a flow battery. Redox couples such as quinones are particularly attractive for this application. No precious metal catalyst is needed because of the fast proton-coupled electron transfer processes. Furthermore, in acid media, the quinones exhibit good chem. stability. These properties render quinone-based redox couples very attractive for high-efficiency metal-free rechargeable batteries. We demonstrate the rechargeability of ORBAT with anthraquinone-2-sulfonic acid or anthraquinone-2,6-disulfonic acid on the neg. side, and 1,2-dihydrobenzoquinone-3,5-disulfonic acid on the pos. side. The ORBAT cell uses a membrane-electrode assembly configuration similar to that used in polymer electrolyte fuel cells. Such a battery can be charged and discharged multiple times at high faradaic efficiency without any noticeable degrdn. of performance. We show that soly. and mass transport properties of the reactants and products are paramount to achieving high current densities and high efficiency. The ORBAT configuration presents a unique opportunity for developing an inexpensive and sustainable metal-free rechargeable battery for large-scale elec. energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFOnsrnO&md5=1bd4bc1ac4fccd7b9d18ea3dce981eb9
      100. 100
        Yang, B.; Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Murali, A.; Prakash, G. K. S.; Narayanan, S. R. High-Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery with Quinone-Based Redox Couples at Both Electrodes J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (7) A1442– A1449 DOI: 10.1149/2.1371607jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        100
        High-Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery with Quinone-Based Redox Couples at Both Electrodes
        Yang, Bo; Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Krishnamoorthy, Sankarganesh; Murali, Advaith; Prakash, G. K. Surya; Narayanan, S. R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (7), A1442-A1449CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The authors demonstrated the repeated cycling of a redox flow cell based on H2O-sol. org. redox couples (ORBAT) at high voltage efficiency, coulombic efficiency and power d. These cells were successfully operated with 4,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,3-disulfonic acid (BQDS) at the pos. electrode and anthraquinone-2,6-disulfonic acid (AQDS) at the neg. electrode. Redn. of the voltage losses arising from mass transport limitations, and understanding of the chem. transformations of BQDS during charging led to these improvements in performance. The specific advances reported here include the use of org. redox couples in the free-acid form, improvements to the flow field configuration, and novel high-surface-area graphite-felt electrode structures. The authors have identified various steps in the chem. and electrochem. transformations of BQDS during the 1st few cycles. Also the crossover of the reactants through the membrane was not significant. The performance improvements and new understanding presented here will hasten the development of ORBAT as an inexpensive and sustainable soln. for large-scale elec. energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XnvFWisL8%253D&md5=e0a2a6f78533a4ea712449f1d7f07a47
      101. 101
        Lalevee, J.; Allonas, X.; Jacques, P. Electronic distribution and solvatochromism investigation of a model radical (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine N-oxyl: tempo) through TD-DFT calculations including PCM solvation J. Mol. Struct.: THEOCHEM 2006, 767 (1–3) 143– 147 DOI: 10.1016/j.theochem.2006.05.054
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        101
        Electronic distribution and solvatochromism investigation of a model radical (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine N-oxyl: tempo) through TD-DFT calculations including PCM solvation
        Lalevee, J.; Allonas, X.; Jacques, P.
        Journal of Molecular Structure: THEOCHEM (2006), 767 (1-3), 143-147CODEN: THEODJ; ISSN:0166-1280. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The solvatochromism of the 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine N-oxyl radical (TEMPO) visible band (n→π*) is reported. When the solvent polarity increases, a blue shift is obsd. that is typical for a n→π* transition. This behavior is well accounted for by time-dependent d. functional theory (TD-DFT) including polarizable continuum model (PCM) solvation in non-specific solvents. However, the agreement between the expts. and the computations for hydroxylic solvents is not straightforward at all. Addnl., valuable information on the electronic/spin distributions and their solvent dependence are presented, a key point for discussing the chem. reactivity of radicals.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XptVGnsbc%253D&md5=4f9d0e231a38786002146ed9f068c27c
      102. 102
        Wei, X.; Xu, W.; Vijayakumar, M.; Cosimbescu, L.; Liu, T.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. TEMPO-Based Catholyte for High-Energy Density Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries Adv. Mater. 2014, 26 (45) 7649– 7653 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201403746
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        102
        TEMPO-Based Catholyte for High-Energy Density Non-aqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Wei, Xiaoliang; Xu, Wu; Vijayakumar, Murugesan; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Liu, Tianbiao; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2014), 26 (45), 7649-7653CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A TEMPO-based non-aq. electrolyte has been developed and evaluated in a hybrid Li|TEMPO redox-flow battery. The TEMPO redox material offers a high redox potential (3.5 V vs. Li/Li+) and a high soly. (2.0 M in the supporting LiPF6 electrolyte), which are key parameters for an electrolyte to achieve high energy d. in flow batteries. The hybrid Li/graphite anode and the FEC SEI-stabilizing additive used to protect the Li anode led to good cyclability for the Li|TEMPO flow batteries at 0.1 M and 0.8 M TEMPO concns. At 2.0 M TEMPO, the Li|TEMPO flow cell delivers an EE of about 70% and a discharge volumetric energy d. of 126 W-h L-1 that exceeds most state-of-the-art aq. and non-aq. flow batteries. Flow battery tests of TEMPO-based electrolytes have demonstrated potential for offering high energy d. - it is also adaptable to other non-aq. redox flow chemistries, for example, as the catholyte in an all-org. flow battery. In addn., we demonstrated that ESR can be used to est. the SOC for nonaq. flow batteries when redox species with unpaired electrons are present.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXitVCitb3P&md5=ba24a1bb387b7321aca56d02e35273be

        Li, Z.; Li, S.; Liu, S.; Huang, K.; Fang, D.; Wang, F.; Peng, S. Electrochemical Properties of an All-Organic Redox Flow Battery Using 2,2,6,6-Tetramethyl-1-Piperidinyloxy and N-Methylphthalimide Electrochem. Solid-State Lett. 2011, 14 (12) A171– A173 DOI: 10.1149/2.012112esl
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Electrochemical Properties of an All-Organic Redox Flow Battery Using 2,2,6,6-Tetramethyl-1-Piperidinyloxy and N-Methylphthalimide
        Li, Zhen; Li, Sha; Liu, Suqin; Huang, Kelong; Fang, Dong; Wang, Fengchao; Peng, Sui
        Electrochemical and Solid-State Letters (2011), 14 (12), A171-A173CODEN: ESLEF6; ISSN:1099-0062. (Electrochemical Society)
        A novel all-org. redox flow battery employing 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy/NaClO4/acetonitrile and N-Methyl- phthalimide/NaClO4/acetonitrile as catholyte and anolyte, resp., is investigated by electrochem. measurements. The quasi-reversible and stable redox reactions are tested by cycle voltammetry. The diffusion coeff. of 0.02 M 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy and 0.02 M N-Methylphthalimide in the supporting electrolyte are all in the range of 0.7-1.1× 10-5 cm2·s-1 at room temp. Stable charge-discharge curves and high coulombic efficiency (90%) for the first 20 cycles are obtained through charge-discharge test.

        Park, S.; Shim, J.; Yang, J.; Shin, K.; Jin, C.; Lee, B.; Lee, Y.; Jeon, J. Electrochemical properties of a non-aqueous redox battery with all-organic redox couples Electrochem. Commun. 2015, 59, 68– 71 DOI: 10.1016/j.elecom.2015.07.013
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        104
        Electrochemical properties of a non-aqueous redox battery with all-organic redox couples
        Park, Se-Kook; Shim, Joonmok; Yang, JungHoon; Shin, Kyoung-Hee; Jin, Chang-Soo; Lee, Bum Suk; Lee, Young-Seak; Jeon, Jae-Deok
        Electrochemistry Communications (2015), 59 (), 68-71CODEN: ECCMF9; ISSN:1388-2481. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A novel all-org. redox cell employing 4-Oxo 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy (4-Oxo TEMPO) (as a catholyte) and (1S)-(+)-Camphorquinone (as an anolyte) is investigated through electrochem. measurements. From cyclic voltammetry tests, it is confirmed that electrochem. reversible redox processes of 4-Oxo TEMPO and (1S)-(+)-Camphorquinone occur at 0.48 V and - 1.64 V (vs. Ag/Ag+), resp. A non-aq. redox battery with these redox couples can yield an estd. open circuit potential of 2.12 V at a 50% state of charge. The charge-discharge performance is assessed with an inhouse designed non-flow single cell. Coulombic and energy efficiencies are 80.3% and 71.3%, resp.

      105. 105
        Takechi, K.; Kato, Y.; Hase, Y. A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Based on a Solvate Ionic Liquid for Rechargeable Flow Batteries Adv. Mater. 2015, 27 (15) 2501– 2506 DOI: 10.1002/adma.201405840
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        105
        A Highly Concentrated Catholyte Based on a Solvate Ionic Liquid for Rechargeable Flow Batteries
        Takechi, Kensuke; Kato, Yuichi; Hase, Yoko
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2015), 27 (15), 2501-2506CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new class of catholyte employing a stabilized supercooled liq. through the combination of a specific org. radical (MT) and plasticizing Li salt (LT) is presented. The catholyte has the unique feature of forming an MT-LT coupled structure to stabilize its supercooled state over a wide temp. range and can be characterized as a "solvated ionic liq.". The addn. of water to this supercooled, liq. does not damage its unique feature of having one of the highest energy densities as a pure liq. using org. redox compd. but improves the parameters required for battery applications, such as viscosity and cond. The performance of a battery with a Li-ion conducting architecture has proved this battery's potential for high-energy-d. flow battery applications because the supercooled liq. consists of environmentally friendly compds. (noncorrosive and heavy-metal-free). This battery has facile scalability and high adaptability for actual flowing architectures. The simple mol. structure of MT and facile prepn. of the catholyte also give a large potential to reduce prodn. costs. The strategy for creating a high-energy-d. catholyte can be used to prep. other org. redox-active liqs. and will be reported.

        Duan, W.; Vemuri, R. S.; Milshtein, J. D.; Laramie, S.; Dmello, R. D.; Huang, J.; Zhang, L.; Hu, D.; Vijayakumar, M.; Wang, W.; Liu, J.; Darling, R. M.; Thompson, L.; Smith, K.; Moore, J. S.; Brushett, F. R.; Wei, X. A symmetric organic-based nonaqueous redox flow battery and its state of charge diagnostics by FTIR J. Mater. Chem. A 2016, 4 (15) 5448– 5456 DOI: 10.1039/C6TA01177B
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        106
        A symmetric organic-based nonaqueous redox flow battery and its state of charge diagnostics by FTIR
        Duan, Wentao; Vemuri, Rama S.; Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Laramie, Sydney; Dmello, Rylan D.; Huang, Jinhua; Zhang, Lu; Hu, Dehong; Vijayakumar, M.; Wang, Wei; Liu, Jun; Darling, Robert M.; Thompson, Levi; Smith, Kyle; Moore, Jeffery S.; Brushett, Fikile R.; Wei, Xiaoliang
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2016), 4 (15), 5448-5456CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Redox flow batteries have shown outstanding promise for grid-scale energy storage to promote utilization of renewable energy and improve grid stability. Nonaq. battery systems can potentially achieve high energy d. because of their broad voltage window. In this paper, we report a new org. redox-active material for use in a nonaq. redox flow battery, 2-phenyl-4,4,5,5-tetramethylimidazoline-1-oxyl-3-oxide (PTIO) that has high soly. (>2.6 M) in org. solvents. PTIO exhibits electrochem. reversible disproportionation reactions and thus can serve as both anolyte and catholyte redox materials in a sym. flow cell. The PTIO flow battery has a moderate cell voltage of ∼1.7 V and shows good cyclability under both cyclic voltammetry and flow cell conditions. Moreover, we demonstrate that FTIR can offer accurate estn. of the PTIO concn. in electrolytes and det. the state of charge of the PTIO flow cell, suggesting FTIR as a powerful online battery status sensor. This study is expected to inspire more insights in this under-addressed area of state of charge anal. aiming at operational safety and reliability of flow batteries.

        Janoschka, T.; Martin, N.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. An Aqueous Redox-Flow Battery with High Capacity and Power: The TEMPTMA/MV System Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55 (46) 14427– 14430 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201606472
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        107
        Aqueous Redox-Flow Battery with High Capacity and Power: The TEMPTMA/MV System
        Janoschka, Tobias; Martin, Norbert; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (46), 14427-14430CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Redox-flow batteries (RFB) can easily store large amts. of elec. energy and thereby mitigate the fluctuating output of renewable power plants. They are widely discussed as energy-storage solns. for wind and solar farms to improve the stability of the elec. grid. Most common RFB concepts are based on strongly acidic metal-salt solns. or poorly performing orgs. Herein the authors present a battery which employs the highly sol. N,N,N-2,2,6,6-heptamethylpiperidinyl oxy-4-NH4Cl (TEMPTMA) and the viologen deriv. N,N'-dimethyl-4,4-bipyridinium dichloride (MV) in a simple and safe aq. soln. as redox-active materials. The resulting battery using these electrolyte solns. has capacities of 54 A-h L-1, giving a total energy d. of 38 Wh L-1 at a cell voltage of 1.4 V. With peak current densities of up to 200 mA cm-2 the TEMPTMA/MV system is a suitable candidate for compact high-capacity and high-power applications.

        Winsberg, J.; Stolze, C.; Schwenke, A.; Muench, S.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. Aqueous 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl Catholytes for a High-Capacity and High Current Density Oxygen-Insensitive Hybrid-Flow Battery ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2 (2) 411– 416 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.6b00655

        Aqueous 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl Catholytes for a High-Capacity and High Current Density Oxygen-Insensitive Hybrid-Flow Battery
        Winsberg, Jan; Stolze, Christian; Schwenke, Almut; Muench, Simon; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (2), 411-416CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Hybrid-flow batteries are a suitable storage technol. for green electricity generated by renewable sources such as wind power and solar energy. Redox-active org. compds. have recently been investigated to improve the traditional metal- and halogen-based technologies. Here the utilization is reported of a 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) deriv. that is in particular designed for application in semiorg. zinc hybrid-flow batteries. The TEMPO deriv. is synthesized and electrochem. characterized via cyclic voltammetry and rotating disc electrode measurements. This deriv. features a high soly. in aq. electrolytes; thus, volumetric capacities > 20 AhL-1 are achieved. The fabricated hybrid-flow batteries feature over 1100 consecutive charge-discharge cycles at const. capacity retention, and current densities up to 80 mAcm-2 are applied.

      111. 111
        Potash, R. A.; McKone, J. R.; Conte, S.; Abruña, H. D. On the Benefits of a Symmetric Redox Flow Battery J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (3) A338– A344 DOI: 10.1149/2.0971602jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        111
        On the Benefits of a Symmetric Redox Flow Battery
        Potash, Rebecca A.; McKone, James R.; Conte, Sean; Abruena, Hector D.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (3), A338-A344CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are of interest for large-scale energy storage, but implementation has been challenged by their low energy d., high complexity, high cost, and insufficient lifetime due to several types of irreversible losses in the electrolyte. To address the issue of system complexity and irreversible losses, we have undertaken a detailed anal. of the concept of the sym. redox flow battery, or SRFB, which relies on a single parent mol. as the charge storage species in both the pos. and neg. electrode reactions. We elaborate on the operating principles and advantages of a SRFB and report the salient electrochem. properties of a class of org. mols., diaminoanthraquinones (DAAQs) as promising candidates for use in SRFB redox electrolytes. Modeling of various modes of operation for SRFBs are presented along with an example of an operational, lab.-scale SRFB based on a DAAQ system.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xos1WntA%253D%253D&md5=6075a88831c4d2449fe9f6eb8cb5205d

        Milshtein, J. D.; Su, L.; Liou, C.; Badel, A. F.; Brushett, F. R. Voltammetry study of quinoxaline in aqueous electrolytes Electrochim. Acta 2015, 180, 695– 704 DOI: 10.1016/j.electacta.2015.07.063
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        112
        Voltammetry study of quinoxaline in aqueous electrolytes
        Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Su, Liang; Liou, Catherine; Badel, Andres F.; Brushett, Fikile R.
        Electrochimica Acta (2015), 180 (), 695-704CODEN: ELCAAV; ISSN:0013-4686. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Org. compds. have recently received considerable attention as active materials in redox flow batteries (RFBs) due to their good electrochem. reversibility, high theor. energy densities, and promise for low cost prodn. Until now, org. active material candidates for aq. RFBs have been limited to the quinone family, a set of arom.-derived org. mols., distinguished by an even no. of ketone (R-C(=O)-R') groups. This work aims to elucidate and optimize the electrochem. behavior of quinoxaline, an org. mol. consisting of fused benzene and pyrazine rings, in aq. electrolytes. More than 30 electrolytes are screened by cyclic voltammetry, and the five most promising electrolytes are investigated further using rotating disk voltammetry. Electrochem. behavior of quinoxaline shows pH dependent thermodn. and reaction mechanisms, while chloride-contg. supporting electrolytes greatly enhance soly. This study sheds light on the promising characteristics of quinoxaline as a low potential compd. for aq. RFBs; quinoxaline has a redox potential of E° ≈ -0.02 V vs. RHE, is sol. up to ∼4.5 M in water, exhibits a two-electron transfer capability, and possesses a low mol. wt. (130.15 g mol-1), resulting in a theor. capacity of 410 mAh g-1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFertLbE&md5=9ebec342c451af5c3e2280f97deaada7
      113. 113
        Sevov, C. S.; Brooner, R. E. M.; Chenard, E.; Assary, R. S.; Moore, J. S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, J.; Sanford, M. S. Evolutionary Design of Low Molecular Weight Organic Anolyte Materials for Applications in Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2015, 137 (45) 14465– 14472 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.5b09572
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        113
        Evolutionary Design of Low Molecular Weight Organic Anolyte Materials for Applications in Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Sevov, Christo S.; Brooner, Rachel E. M.; Chenard, Etienne; Assary, Rajeev S.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Rodriguez-Lopez, Joaquin; Sanford, Melanie S.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2015), 137 (45), 14465-14472CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The integration of renewable energy sources into the elec. grid requires low-cost energy storage systems that mediate the variable and intermittent flux of energy assocd. with most renewables. Nonaq. redox-flow batteries have emerged as a promising technol. for grid-scale energy storage applications. Because the cost of the system scales with mass, the electroactive materials must have a low equiv. wt. (ideally 150 g/(mol·e-) or less), and must function with low mol. wt. supporting electrolytes such as LiBF4. However, sol. anolyte materials that undergo reversible redox processes in the presence of Li-ion supports are rare. We report the evolutionary design of a series of pyridine-based anolyte materials that exhibit up to two reversible redox couples at low potentials in the presence of Li-ion supporting electrolytes. A combination of cyclic voltammetry of anolyte candidates and independent synthesis of their corresponding charged-states was performed to rapidly screen for the most promising candidates. Results of this workflow provided evidence for possible decompn. pathways of first-generation materials and guided synthetic modifications to improve the stability of anolyte materials under the targeted conditions. This iterative process led to the identification of a promising anolyte material, N-Me 4-acetylpyridinium tetrafluoroborate. This compd. is sol. in nonaq. solvents, is prepd. in a single synthetic step, has a low equiv. wt. of 111 g/(mol·e-), and undergoes two reversible 1e- redns. in the presence of LiBF4 to form reduced products that are stable over days in soln.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVSktLfI&md5=de98cc11fb73aa3b765efb4ace23832b
      114. 114
        Sevov, C. S.; Hickey, D. P.; Cook, M. E.; Robinson, S. G.; Barnett, S.; Minteer, S. D.; Sigman, M. S.; Sanford, M. S. Physical Organic Approach to Persistent, Cyclable, Low-Potential Electrolytes for Flow Battery Applications J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139 (8) 2924– 2927 DOI: 10.1021/jacs.7b00147
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        114
        Physical Organic Approach to Persistent, Cyclable, Low-Potential Electrolytes for Flow Battery Applications
        Sevov, Christo S.; Hickey, David P.; Cook, Monique E.; Robinson, Sophia G.; Barnett, Shoshanna; Minteer, Shelley D.; Sigman, Matthew S.; Sanford, Melanie S.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (8), 2924-2927CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The deployment of nonaq. redox flow batteries for grid-scale energy storage has been impeded by a lack of electrolytes that undergo redox events at as low (anolyte) or high (catholyte) potentials as possible while exhibiting the stability and cycling lifetimes necessary for a battery device. Herein, we report a new approach to electrolyte design that uses phys. org. tools for the predictive targeting of electrolytes that possess this combination of properties. We apply this approach to the identification of a new pyridinium-based anolyte that undergoes 1e- electrochem. charge-discharge cycling at low potential (-1.21 V vs Fc/Fc+) to a 95% state-of-charge without detectable capacity loss after 200 cycles.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXivVyrsLg%253D&md5=eb9ae6a6d73d951f3085bf06708b75c8
      115. 115
        Kaur, A. P.; Holubowitch, N. E.; Ergun, S.; Elliott, C. F.; Odom, S. A. A Highly Soluble Organic Catholyte for Non-Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries Energy Technol. 2015, 3 (5) 476– 480 DOI: 10.1002/ente.201500020
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        115
        A Highly Soluble Organic Catholyte for Non-Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Kaur, Aman Preet; Holubowitch, Nicolas E.; Ergun, Selin; Elliott, Corrine F.; Odom, Susan A.
        Energy Technology (Weinheim, Germany) (2015), 3 (5), 476-480CODEN: ETNEFN; ISSN:2194-4296. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A phenothiazine deriv. with high soly. in carbonate solvents contg. lithium salts showed extensive overcharge protection and, as a result, has been evaluated as a catholyte for non-aq. redox flow batteries. We report the testing of 3,7-bis(trifluoromethyl)-N-ethylphenothiazine as a catholyte and 2,3,6-trimethylquinoxaline as the anolyte in redox flow batteries contg. 0.05, 0.15, and 0.35 M active material and found the longest capacity retention over about 60 cycles at 0.15 M. To our knowledge, this is the most sol. catholyte candidate with a robust radical cation.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXosVCiurw%253D&md5=5f35c2c913da2684fd3fa29257b7c624
      116. 116
        Milshtein, J. D.; Kaur, A. P.; Casselman, M. D.; Kowalski, J. A.; Modekrutti, S.; Zhang, P. L.; Harsha Attanayake, N.; Elliott, C. F.; Parkin, S. R.; Risko, C.; Brushett, F. R.; Odom, S. A. High current density, long duration cycling of soluble organic active species for non-aqueous redox flow batteries Energy Environ. Sci. 2016, 9 (11) 3531– 3543 DOI: 10.1039/C6EE02027E
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        116
        High current density, long duration cycling of soluble organic active species for non-aqueous redox flow batteries
        Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Kaur, Aman Preet; Casselman, Matthew D.; Kowalski, Jeffrey A.; Modekrutti, Subrahmanyam; Zhang, Peter L.; Harsha Attanayake, N.; Elliott, Corrine F.; Parkin, Sean R.; Risko, Chad; Brushett, Fikile R.; Odom, Susan A.
        Energy & Environmental Science (2016), 9 (11), 3531-3543CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Non-aq. redox flow batteries (NAqRFBs) employing redox-active org. mols. show promise to meet requirements for grid energy storage. Here, we combine the rational design of org. mols. with flow cell engineering to boost NAqRFB performance. We synthesize two highly sol. phenothiazine derivs., N-(2-methoxyethyl)phenothiazine (MEPT) and N-[2-(2-methoxyethoxy)ethyl]phenothiazine (MEEPT), via a one-step synthesis from inexpensive precursors. Synthesis and isolation of the radical-cation salts permit UV-vis decay studies that illustrate the high stability of these open-shell species. Cyclic voltammetry and bulk electrolysis expts. reveal the promising electrochem. properties of MEPT and MEEPT under dil. conditions. A high performance non-aq. flow cell, employing interdigitated flow fields and carbon paper electrodes, is engineered and demonstrated; polarization and impedance studies quantify the cell's low area-specific resistance (3.2-3.3 Ω cm2). We combine the most sol. deriv., MEEPT, and its tetrafluoroborate radical-cation salt in the flow cell for sym. cycling, evincing a c.d. of 100 mA cm-2 with undetectable capacity fade over 100 cycles. This coincident high c.d. and capacity retention is unprecedented in NAqRFB literature.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsFWlsrrI&md5=51155c9921b6ba9da123d44542a8675b
      117. 117
        Lin, K.; Gomez-Bombarelli, R.; Beh, E. S.; Tong, L.; Chen, Q.; Valle, A.; Aspuru-Guzik, A.; Aziz, M. J.; Gordon, R. G. A redox-flow battery with an alloxazine-based organic electrolyte Nat. Energy 2016, 1, 16102 DOI: 10.1038/nenergy.2016.102
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        117
        A redox-flow battery with an alloxazine-based organic electrolyte
        Lin, Kaixiang; Gomez-Bombarelli, Rafael; Beh, Eugene S.; Tong, Liuchuan; Chen, Qing; Valle, Alvaro; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Aziz, Michael J.; Gordon, Roy G.
        Nature Energy (2016), 1 (9), 16102CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Redox-flow batteries (RFBs) can store large amts. of elec. energy from variable sources, such as solar and wind. Recently, redox-active org. mols. in aq. RFBs have drawn substantial attention due to their rapid kinetics and low membrane crossover rates. Drawing inspiration from nature, here we report a high-performance aq. RFB utilizing an org. redox compd., alloxazine, which is a tautomer of the isoalloxazine backbone of vitamin B2. It can be synthesized in high yield at room temp. by single-step coupling of inexpensive o-phenylenediamine derivs. and alloxan. The highly alk.-sol. alloxazine 7/8-carboxylic acid produces a RFB exhibiting open-circuit voltage approaching 1.2 V and current efficiency and capacity retention exceeding 99.7% and 99.98% per cycle, resp. Theor. studies indicate that structural modification of alloxazine with electron-donating groups should allow further increases in battery voltage. As an aza-arom. mol. that undergoes reversible redox cycling in aq. electrolyte, alloxazine represents a class of radical-free redox-active orgs. for use in large-scale energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVersrY%253D&md5=1bdb2e213c96396bad489b2404fbc367

        Orita, A.; Verde, M. G.; Sakai, M.; Meng, Y. S. A biomimetic redox flow battery based on flavin mononucleotide Nat. Commun. 2016, 7, 13230 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms13230
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A biomimetic redox flow battery based on flavin mononucleotide
        Orita, Akihiro; Verde, Michael G.; Sakai, Masanori; Meng, Ying Shirley
        Nature Communications (2016), 7 (), 13230CODEN: NCAOBW; ISSN:2041-1723. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The versatility in design of redox flow batteries makes them apt to efficiently store energy in large-scale applications at low cost. The discovery of inexpensive org. electroactive materials for use in aq. flow battery electrolytes is highly attractive, but is thus far limited. Here we report on a flow battery using an aq. electrolyte based on the sodium salt of FMN. Flavins are highly versatile electroactive mols., which catalyze a multitude of redox reactions in biol. systems. We use nicotinamide (vitamin B3) as a hydrotropic agent to enhance the water soly. of FMN. A redox flow battery using FMN neg. and ferrocyanide pos. electrolytes in strong base shows stable cycling performance, with over 99% capacity retention over the course of 100 cycles. We hypothesize that this is enabled due to the oxidized and reduced forms of FMN-Na being stabilized by resonance structures.

        Yu, J.; Hu, Y.; Pan, F.; Zhang, Z.; Wang, Q.; Li, H.; Huang, X.; Chen, L. A class of liquid anode for rechargeable batteries with ultralong cycle life Nat. Commun. 2017, 8, 14629 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms14629
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        121
        A class of liquid anode for rechargeable batteries with ultralong cycle life
        Yu Juezhi; Hu Yong-Sheng; Zhang Zhizhen; Li Hong; Huang Xuejie; Chen Liquan; Pan Feng; Wang Qing
        Nature communications (2017), 8 (), 14629 ISSN:.
        Low cost, highly efficient and safe devices for energy storage have long been desired in our society. Among these devices, electrochemical batteries with alkali metal anodes have attracted worldwide attention. However, the practical application of such systems is limited by dendrite formation and low cycling efficiency of alkali metals. Here we report a class of liquid anodes fabricated by dissolving sodium metal into a mixed solution of biphenyl and ethers. Such liquid anodes are highly safe and have a low redox potential of 0.09 V versus sodium, exhibiting a high conductivity of 1.2 × 10(-2) S cm(-1). When coupled with polysulfides dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide as the cathode, a battery is demonstrated to sustain over 3,500 cycles without measureable capacity loss at room temperature. This work provides a base for exploring a family of liquid anodes for rechargeable batteries that potentially meet the requirements for grid-scale electrical energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1czjtFagsw%253D%253D&md5=9992cba0c39249795312f1c5884cd6e1

        A metal-free and all-organic redox flow battery with polythiophene as the electroactive species
        Oh, S. H.; Lee, C.-W.; Chun, D. H.; Jeon, J.-D.; Shim, J.; Shin, K. H.; Yang, J. H.
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2014), 2 (47), 19994-19998CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A metal-free and all-org. redox flow battery is proposed and investigated. It employs polythiophene microparticles dispersed in electrolyte solns. as the redox couple and does not depend on limited metal resources. It shows a high cell potential and stable charge/discharge performance with a high energy efficiency of 60.9%.

        Wu, M.; Bhargav, A.; Cui, Y.; Siegel, A.; Agarwal, M.; Ma, Y.; Fu, Y. Highly Reversible Diphenyl Trisulfide Catholyte for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries ACS Energy Lett. 2016, 1 (6) 1221– 1226 DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.6b00533
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        123
        Highly Reversible Diphenyl Trisulfide Catholyte for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries
        Wu, Min; Bhargav, Amruth; Cui, Yi; Siegel, Amanda; Agarwal, Mangilal; Ma, Ying; Fu, Yongzhu
        ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (6), 1221-1226CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Organotrisulfide (RSSSR) is a new class of high-capacity cathode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries. The org. R group can tune the structure and property of organotrisulfide as well as electrochem. performance in batteries. Herein, a nominal di-Ph trisulfide (DPTS, C6H5SSSC6H5) catholyte is reported for rechargeable lithium batteries. Three sulfur atoms allow 4e- storage per mol., affording DPTS with a theor. capacity of 428 mAh g-1. The DPTS catholyte is synthesized from a coupling reaction of di-Ph disulfide (DPDS) and elemental sulfur in liq. electrolyte at 70°. It is found that the DPTS catholyte is a mixt. of DPTS, DPDS, and elemental sulfur in the electrolyte. The lithium cell with the DPTS catholyte delivers an initial specific capacity of 330 mAh g-1DPTS and retains 79% of the initial capacity over 100 cycles at the C/2 rate. The cell delivers an initial discharge specific energy of 751 Wh kg-1DPTS with a high energy efficiency of over 95% at the C/5 rate. The achievable energy d. of the DPTS catholyte (1.0 M) is 158 Wh L-1. This study shows that DPTS is a promising high-capacity cathode material for highly reversible lithium batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVGqsbjO&md5=acce806ed445df8ab75342063ca5f158

        Zhang, H.; Zhang, H.; Li, X.; Mai, Z.; Zhang, J. Nanofiltration (NF) membranes: the next generation separators for all vanadium redox flow batteries (VRBs)? Energy Environ. Sci. 2011, 4 (5) 1676– 1679 DOI: 10.1039/c1ee01117k
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        124
        Nanofiltration (NF) membranes: the next generation separators for all vanadium redox flow batteries (VRBs)
        Zhang, Hongzhang; Zhang, Huamin; Li, Xianfeng; Mai, Zhensheng; Zhang, Jianlu
        Energy & Environmental Science (2011), 4 (5), 1676-1679CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        NF membranes, as an alternative to traditional ion exchange membranes, were first proposed and successfully prepd. for VRBs based on a totally new concept of tuning the vanadium/proton selectivity via pore size exclusion. The results showed that membranes show increasing vanadium ion/proton (V/H) selectivity with decreasing pore size distribution. VRBs assembled with prepd. NF membranes exhibited comparable performance to that of commercialized Nafion. The concept could potentially overcome the traditional restriction from ion exchange membranes and provide much more material options for VRB membranes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXmslOjtLc%253D&md5=1c5efeb1b94c8f70f5c7edcd1328cdfa

        Wei, X.; Nie, Z.; Luo, Q.; Li, B.; Chen, B.; Simmons, K.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. Nanoporous Polytetrafl uoroethylene/Silica Composite Separator as a High-Performance All-Vanadium Redox Flow Battery Membrane Adv. Energy Mater. 2013, 3 (9) 1215– 1220 DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201201112
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        125
        Nanoporous Polytetrafluoroethylene/Silica Composite Separator as a High-Performance All-Vanadium Redox Flow Battery Membrane
        Wei, Xiaoliang; Nie, Zimin; Luo, Qingtao; Li, Bin; Chen, Baowei; Simmons, Kevin; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
        Advanced Energy Materials (2013), 3 (9), 1215-1220CODEN: ADEMBC; ISSN:1614-6840. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        A novel low-cost nanoporous polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)/silica composite separator has been prepd. and evaluated for its use in an all-vanadium redox flow battery (VRB). The separator consists of silica particles enmeshed in a PTFE fibril matrix. It possesses unique nanoporous structures with an av. pore size of 38 nm and a porosity of 48%. These pores function as the ion transport channels during redox flow battery operation. This separator provides excellent electrochem. performance in the mixed-acid VRB system. The VRB using this separator delivers impressive energy efficiency, rate capability, and temp. tolerance. In addn., the flow cell using the novel separator also demonstrates an exceptional capacity retention capability over extended cycling, thus offering excellent stability for long-term operation. The characteristics of low cost, excellent electrochem. performance and proven chem. stability afford the PTFE/silica nanoporous separator great potential as a substitute for the Nafion membrane used in VRB applications.

      128. 128
        Su, L.; Darling, R. M.; Gallagher, K. G.; Xie, W.; Thelen, J. L.; Badel, A. F.; Barton, J. L.; Cheng, K. J.; Balsara, N. P.; Moore, J. S.; Brushett, F. R. An Investigation of the Ionic Conductivity and Species Crossover of Lithiated Nafion 117 in Nonaqueous Electrolytes J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (1) A5253– A5262 DOI: 10.1149/2.03211601jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        128
        An Investigation of the Ionic Conductivity and Species Crossover of Lithiated Nafion 117 in Nonaqueous Electrolytes
        Su, Liang; Darling, Robert M.; Gallagher, Kevin G.; Xie, Wei; Thelen, Jacob L.; Badel, Andres F.; Barton, John L.; Cheng, Kevin J.; Balsara, Nitash P.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Brushett, Fikile R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5253-A5262CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        Nonaq. redox flow batteries are a fast-growing area of research and development motivated by the need to develop low-cost energy storage systems. The identification of a highly conductive, yet selective membrane, is of paramount importance to enabling such a technol. Herein, we report the swelling behavior, ionic cond., and species crossover of lithiated Nafion 117 membranes immersed in three nonaq. electrolytes (PC, PC : EC, and DMSO). Our results show that solvent vol. fraction within the membrane has the greatest effect on both cond. and crossover. An approx. linear relationship between diffusive crossover of neutral redox species (ferrocene) and the ionic cond. of membrane was obsd. As a secondary effect, the charge on redox species modifies crossover rates in accordance with Donnan exclusion. The selectivity of membrane is derived math. and compared to exptl. results reported here. The relatively low selectivity for lithiated Nafion 117 in nonaq. conditions suggests that new membranes are required for competitive nonaq. redox flow batteries to be realized. Potential design rules are suggested for the future membrane engineering work.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr3P&md5=174ba18899d02b48ba4cbe014c093a5a
      129. 129
        Small, L. J.; Pratt, H. D.; Fujimoto, C. H.; Anderson, T. M. Diels Alder Polyphenylene Anion Exchange Membrane for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163 (1) A5106– A5111 DOI: 10.1149/2.0141601jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        129
        Diels Alder Polyphenylene Anion Exchange Membrane for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Small, Leo J.; Pratt, Harry D., III; Fujimoto, Cy H.; Anderson, Travis M.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5106-A5111CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        Here highly conductive, solvent-resistant anionic Diels Alder polyphenylene (DAPP) membranes were synthesized with three different ionic contents and tested in an ionic liq.-based nonaq. redox flow battery (RFB). These membranes display 3-10× increase in cond. in propylene carbonate compared to some com. available (aq.) anion exchange membranes. The membrane with an ion content of 1.5 meq/g (DAPP1.5) proved too brittle for operation in a RFB, while the membrane with an ion content of 2.5 meq/g (DAPP2.5) allowed excessive movement of solvent and poor electrochem. yields (capacity fade). Despite having lower voltage efficiencies compared to DAPP2.5, the membrane with an intermediate ion content of 2.0 meq/g (DAPP2.0) exhibited higher coulombic efficiencies (96.4% vs. 89.1%) and electrochem. yields (21.6% vs. 10.9%) after 50 cycles. Crossover of the electroactive species was the primary reason for decreased electrochem. yields. Anal. of the anolyte and catholyte revealed degrdn. of the electroactive species and formation of a film at the membrane-soln. interface. Increases in membrane resistance were attributed to mech. and thermal aging of the membrane; no chem. change was obsd. Improvements in the ionic selectivity and ionic cond. of the membrane will increase the electrochem. yield and voltage efficiency of future nonaq. redox flow batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr%252FP&md5=c3c6c67e1f4669fd89eae4fd7e9fccb0
      130. 130
        Hudak, N. S.; Small, L. J.; Pratt, H. D.; Anderson, T. M. Through-Plane Conductivities of Membranes for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries J. Electrochem. Soc. 2015, 162 (10) A2188– A2194 DOI: 10.1149/2.0901510jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        130
        Through-Plane Conductivities of Membranes for Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Hudak, Nicholas S.; Small, Leo J.; Pratt, Harry D.; Anderson, Travis M.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2015), 162 (10), A2188-A2194CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        Nonaq. redox flow batteries (RFB) leverage nonaq. solvents to enable higher operating voltages compared to their aq. counterparts. Most com. components for flow batteries, however, are designed for aq. use. One crit. component, the ion-selective membrane, provides ionic conductance between electrodes while preventing crossover of electroactive species. Here we evaluate the area-specific conductances and through-plane conductivities of com. available microporous separators (Celgard 2400, 2500) and anion exchange membranes (Neosepta AFX, Neosepta AHA, Fumasep FAP-450, Fumasep FAP-PK) soaked in acetonitrile, propylene carbonate, or two imidazolium-based ionic liqs. Fumasep membranes combined with acetonitrile-based electrolyte solns. provided the highest conductance values and conductivities by far. When tested in ionic liqs., all anion exchange membranes displayed conductivities greater than those of the Celgard microporous separators, though the separators' decreased thickness-enabled conductances on par with the most conductive anion exchange membranes. Ionic cond. is not the only consideration when choosing an anion exchange membrane; testing of FAP-450 and FAP-PK membranes in a nonaq. RFB demonstrated that the increased mech. stability of PEEK-supported FAP-PK minimized swelling, in turn decreasing solvent mediated crossover and enabling greater electrochem. yields (40% vs. 4%) and Coulombic efficiencies (94% vs. 90%) compared to the unsupported, higher conductance FAP-450.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtlOntb7K&md5=7514f35e84b7df1a623aed9a65275df9
      131. 131
        Luo, Q.; Li, L.; Wang, W.; Nie, Z.; Wei, X.; Li, B.; Chen, B.; Yang, Z. G.; Sprenkle, V. Capacity Decay and Remediation of Nafion-based All-Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries ChemSusChem 2013, 6 (2) 268– 274 DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201200730
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        131
        Capacity Decay and Remediation of Nafion-based All-Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries
        Luo, Qingtao; Li, Liyu; Wang, Wei; Nie, Zimin; Wei, Xiaoliang; Li, Bin; Chen, Baowei; Yang, Zhenguo; Sprenkle, Vincent
        ChemSusChem (2013), 6 (2), 268-274CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The relation between electrochem. performance of V redox flow batteries (VRBs) and electrolyte compn. is studied, and the reasons for capacity decay over charge-discharge cycling are analyzed and discussed herein. The reasons for capacity fading over real charge-discharge cycling include the lack of balance between the V active species and the asym. valence of V ions in pos. and neg. electrolytes. The asym. valence of V ions leads to a state-of-charge (SOC)-range decrease in pos. electrolytes and a SOC-range increase in neg. electrolytes. As a result, the higher SOC range in neg. half-cells further aggravates capacity fading by creating a higher overpotential and possible H evolution. Based on this finding, the authors developed 2 methods for restoring lost capacity, thereby enabling long-term operation of VRBs to be achieved without the substantial loss of energy resulting from periodic total re-mixing of electrolytes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslKntbrN&md5=bbdc9fcccb63015a236ddb1d90592d70
